pageElements.text: If you live in a cold area, you won’t need much convincing that heated surfaces inside your car are a good idea. Having the seat you’re sitting in warm you, electric blanket style, is a great way to start the day in winter. Increasingly, heated front seats are a surprisingly affordable option on a wide range of vehicles.

But heating and cooling inside the car goes even further than that. Here’s our list of ways you can get comfortable in all kinds of weather, something you’ll want to keep in mind next time you go new-vehicle shopping. Call these unnecessary frills if you want, but we’re calling them quality-of-life enhancements.

1. Heated front seats. You will find heated seats in the front on an increasing number of vehicles. For example, the 2016 Chevrolet Traverse (starting just under $30,000) offers them as a stand-alone option at only $250 or bundled into an option package that includes infotainment, navigation, and variable-effort power steering for $1,000. The 2016 Acura ILX, priced starting in the high $20,000s, has standard heated front seats on every model. They’re also standard on the 2016 Toyota Corolla LE Premium, which starts around $22,000.

2. Heated rear seats. This feature is harder to find, but worth it if you frequently have back-seat passengers. Generally you’ll notice that only the outboard seats are included. Too bad for the poor slob who sits in the center of the back seat. Amazingly, you can get this feature even in the $20,000 2016 Kia Forte EX subcompact, as part of the Premium Plus package ($3,000), which bundles heated front and rear seats, plus a ventilated driver’s seat with three fan speeds. On the more upscale (mid-$30,000s) 2016 Lincoln MKZ, the $4,420 Reserve Equipment group includes heated and cooled front seats, heated rear seats, and much more. On the Range Rover Supercharged LWB ($104,190), as pictured above, you get a screenful of choices, including "massage."

3. Ventilated/cooling seats. Many people feel these feel weird—refrigeration coming up from underneath, and all. There’s nothing like them on a hot day, or even a regular day when the car has been parked in a sunny spot. They generally recirculate cabin air through the perforations in leather seats. The 2016 Ford Explorer Limited, which starts in the low $40,000s, has standard heated and ventilated front seats. The luxurious 2016 Cadillac XTS Luxury model (starting around $50,000) includes heated and ventilated front seats plus heated outboard rear seats as standard equipment.

4. Heated steering wheel. A true luxury that lets you dispense with the gloves in winter, these can also be too much of a good thing. The most desirable are those that either shut off automatically after a time (as on the mid-$60,000s Mercedes-Benz GL450, where it’s a $250 option), or, as on the 2016 Lexus GX460’s top Luxury trim (low $60,000s), with a heating element that monitors and adjusts heating levels to maintain a comfortable temperature. Pictured at the top of the page is the 2017 Genesis G90, not yet priced, which includes the heated steering wheel as standard.

5. Heated and cooled cup holders. This is a rare but worthy option. You’ll find it on high-end vehicles like the mid-$60,000s 2016 Mercedes-Benz GL350, where it’s part of the $4,410 Premium package. (The 2015 model is pictured.) You’ll want to experiment to find the right height of cup to take advantage of the heating or cooling feature; this is a keep warm (or cold) feature, not something that will nuke your already-lukewarm coffee or ice your soda.

With a name like Armada, you know Nissan is not trying to tiptoe around the fact that this is a big, really big, I'm saying humongous vehicle. Nissan was using words like "capable," "strong," "durable," and "authentic" to describe the new Armada, and those work, too.

This all-new, second-generation version of the largest sport-utility vehicle from Nissan is not based on the Titan pickup, also all new for 2016, but on the Patrol SUV, sold in many countries outside the United States and built in Japan. That's where the 2017 Nissan Armada will be assembled, too, rather than in Mississippi as before. The Mississippi plant is saving its capacity for the new Titan, Nissan's spokesman said.
If you want a high-riding, capacious SUV, this is one to look at, and attractive touches such as a ruched leather treatment on the door inserts make it worth your while.

There are three trim levels: SV, SL, and Platinum. All get navigation, heated front-row seats, and a thirteen-speaker Bose audio system as standard. There are numerous available active safety features: predictive forward collision warning, backup collision intervention, intelligent cruise control, lane departure prevention and warning systems, and blind spot warning and intervention.
The Armada swaps the previous five-speed automatic transmission for a seven-speed, and the 390-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8 is up by 73 horsepower over the outgoing engine.

If you want a high-riding, seriously capacious SUV, this is one to look at. A few of its more attractive touches, such as a ruched leather treatment on the door inserts and heavy chrome on the exterior, will make it worth your while to do so.

The real fun at Nissan at this auto show will be the Winter Warrior Pathfinder, Murano, and Rogue, each wearing four-foot-long snowshoe tracks where the tires are supposed to be. These ought to be popular at McCormick Place during the show. Can't wait to see them for ourselves.

pageElements.text: If you aren’t already worried enough about your teenager getting behind the wheel of a car, here are a few sobering statistics. According to a new report from personal-finance site Nerdwallet, drivers aged sixteen to nineteen are almost three times more likely to get into a fatal car crash than older drivers. And the risk is not only to their health, but your money—or theirs, depending on who is paying the insurance premium. If teen drivers get a speeding ticket or are convicted of driving under the influence, their rates will, on average, go up three times more than an adult driver with the same stain on his or her driving record. That's on top of the bump in insurance rates you'll already see from adding a teenager to your family insurance policy. The expense is bad enough, but of course the risk to your child’s life and limb is far worse.
Fortunately, there are some things you can do that will help keep insurance costs down while helping keep your youthful family members safer on the road at the same time.

1. Extra driver education.

Not every state even requires new drivers to start with a formal driver education course, but you as the parent should find one anyway. A study by the University of Nebraska-Lincoln says taking driver ed classes will cut the chance of a teen getting a moving violation by 43 percent and the risk of getting into a car accident by 14 percent. The full study is here, if you want to see the details.

Some insurance companies will give you a discount, averaging around 10 percent, if your teen driver graduates from a driving course: Travelers, Allstate, Liberty Mutual, and State Farm are among them. Liberty Mutual even gives a discount for teens who complete its TeenSmart online driver safety class.

An important caveat, though: the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, citing several studies, says high-performance driving schools that teach skills such as skid control could actually increase the risk that young, especially male, drivers will become overconfident and raise the risk they'll crash. We at JKC are still in favor of getting your teenager as much defensive driving instruction as you can afford and find time for. Two highly reputable multi-location schools that know how to keep the focus on safety for new drivers are the Skip Barber and Bob Bondurant driving schools.
Some studies say high-performance driving lessons may raise the risk of teen crashes, but we at JKC favor as much skill improvement education as you can afford.

2. A driver contract.

This is your opportunity to have a conversation with your child and set some limits that are put down on paper. The Allstate Foundation has an excellent teen safe driving contract to download, with versions that take every state's teen driver regulations into account, in both English and Spanish. Most insurance companies offer these, although you won't get a direct discount for filling it out.

3. No car at college.

College students should go to school without the car. You can get an average of seven percent lower rates from many insurance companies. This discount is for a family policy that includes young drivers who are off at school at least 100 miles away from home and don't have the insured vehicle with them. The student will still be on the insurance policy, but the insurer is discounting on the basis that he or she will only be driving the insured vehicles on breaks and vacations.

4. Good grades pay off, literally.

Most auto insurers will discount teen drivers' rates if they have at least a B average and can prove it by showing a report card. Insurance companies generally offer this for both high school and college students. This is not just a gold star from your insurance provider. The discount is backed up by research showing more successful students tend to be safer drivers. As the parent, there's not too much you can do to make top grades happen—sadly—but if your teenager is getting decent grades, don't miss the chance to use it to save money on car insurance.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact coupe
Price as tested (estimated): $28,000
Trim levels: LX, LX-P, EX-T, EX-L, Touring
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 174 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 31 mpg city/41 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
My favorite standard feature: Heated leather seats
Options I can’t live without: Collision mitigation braking (standard with Touring trim)
Notable standard features on this model: Seventeen-inch alloy wheels, LED headlights, rain-sensing wipers, dual-zone automatic climate control, leather-wrapped shift knob and steering wheel, trip computer, seven-inch touchscreen with display audio, satellite navigation with voice recognition, Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, Pandora compatibility, SMS text messaging, Bluetooth, ten-speaker premium audio, compass, forward collision warning and collision mitigation braking, lane departure warning and assist, adaptive cruise control

You might also be considering: Subaru BRZ, Toyota (Scion) FR-S and tC

The new Civic coupe has arrived, the second installment of a Civic series that will be the most comprehensive in the forty-three-year history of this Honda mainstay, with a five-door hatchback, a hybrid, and two performance versions (high and higher) still to come.

The immediate question that arises in considering a car in the thinly populated compact coupe category is this: Why would I prefer a two-door to the greater utility of a sedan? The answer to that question accounts for the sparsity this class. Most buyers opt for four doors.
Those who eschew a second set of doors prioritize style and image above all else. And the latest Civic coupe is loaded with both.

While the sedan is no wallflower, and represents a welcome departure from Honda’s usual caution with four-door designs, the coupe’s styling is a little edgier, with more creases in the sheetmetal,  a tightly-wrapped exterior treatment that looks more athletic.

It also embodies tidier dimensions. The coupe shares the sedan’s 106.3-inch wheelbase, a 3.1-inch stretch versus the previous generation. But at 176.9 inches, the new coupe is an inch shorter than the previous version, 1.8 inches wider at 70.8 inches, a smidge (0.1 inch) lower at 54.9 inches, with much wider track: 60.9 inches front, 61.5 rear, increases of 1.9 and 1.6 inches, respectively.
If the image objective is cool and athletic, the Civic has it covered. It’s lean, sexy, and ready to rock and roll.
And even though the coupe is an inch shorter, its overhangs—the portions of the car that extend beyond the front and rear axles—have shrunk even more, by 1.4 inches front, 3.0 inches rear.
Compared with the new sedan, the coupe is 5.4 inches shorter, and it’s almost an inch lower.
If the image objective is cool and athletic, the Civic has it covered. It’s lean, sexy, and ready to rock and roll.

The coupe shares the sedan’s engine choices: a 158-horsepower four-cylinder, available only in the basic LX and EX models, and a turbocharged 1.5-liter four. Both engines are new, and the turbo is a first for Hondas sold in the U.S. We will undoubtedly see others.

The base engine offers a choice between a six-speed manual transmission (only on the base LX) and a continuously variable automatic (CVT). Turbo engines are allied with the CVT. Those combos will be the case when the coupe reaches showrooms in mid-March, although Honda plans to make a manual transmission available with the turbo later this year, with all models—coupes, sedans, and hatchbacks.

At the press preview earlier this month in San Diego, all the coupes were equipped with the turbo engine and CVT. However, there was one development mule, a sedan, with the 1.5-liter turbo and the six-speed manual, which we took for a very brief drive and emerged wondering why Honda has delayed this combination so long.
As an aside, we wondered why this development mule was heavily camouflaged, and were told that Honda didn’t want this car to be perceived as a production model. Not much chance of that.

With its tidier dimensions, and the extensive use of high-strength steel in its body shell, the coupe weighs in a bit lighter than its predecessor. It's also lighter than the corresponding sedan models; for example, the Touring trim level of the Civic sedan weighs 2,293 pounds, versus 2,888 for the Touring level of the Civic coupe.

What this will yield in terms of acceleration is a test track question, but we expect the turbo-powered CVT coupe to sprint to 60 mph in less than seven seconds. Tramp on the gas from a dead stop, and the turbo spools up almost instantly, no waiting. Passing power is plentiful, and torque steer—the tendency in some powerful front-wheel-drive cars for the drive wheels to pull to left or right during hard acceleration from a stop—is a non-issue.

We should also add that Honda’s work with CVT development shows to good advantage here. There’s little of the feel that once plagued this transmissions—the sense of the engine and transmission being out of synch during hard acceleration—and at full throttle this CVT provides simulated upshifts that feel like a conventional automatic.

While acceleration is respectable, the coupe’s real forte is agility—it feels even handier than the sedan. The sedan gets high marks for its solid structure, but the coupe takes chassis rigidity a step further, with selective stiffening around front and rear suspension mounting points, as well as firmer suspension tuning.

The suspension components vary slightly across the various trim levels, but the bottom line overall is a coupe that’s quick on its feet, with eager responses to orders from the driver. Body motions are modest, even in hard cornering, and there’s absolutely no drama. It’s easy to be precise with this car in quick maneuvers, thanks to electric power steering that’s exceptionally quick (2.2 turns lock to lock), accurate, and tactile. And the steering wheel enhances the experience, with its just-right rim thickness and grippy feel.

There are limits to the coupe’s agility, of course. Like almost any front-wheel-drive car, the weight bias is decidedly forward, over the front wheels, which is the classic prescription for understeer—the faster the car is pushed into a corner, the more it wants to go straight.

The Civic coupe is no exception, but its understeer is progressive, and furnishes plenty of notice when the driver is exceeding its cornering limits. A more performance-oriented tire would probably raise the understeer threshold—like most new cars, all the Civics are equipped with all-season rubber—and would probably shorten braking distances.
On the other hand, the brake system allows easy pressure modulation at the pedal, and is fade free, i.e., repeated hard stops won’t diminish performance.
The new Civics raise the standard for quiet operation among compact cars.

On the comfort side of the ledger, the slightly firmer suspension tuning doesn’t have a negative effect on ride quality; it’s compliant enough to take the edge off edgy bumps and expansion joints. And Honda’s efforts with sound insulation pays off here, just as it does in the sedan. The new Civics raise the standard for quiet operation among compact cars.

Inside, the coupe sustains the high-quality materials established by the sedan, including first-rate bucket seats as well as a rear seat actually habitable by adults. Although the new car is an inch shorter than the previous coupe, and substantially shorter than the sedan, Honda’s interior designers—long celebrated for finding space inside that seem impossible for a given set of exterior dimensions—have expanded rear-seat legroom by 2.2 inches.

The stretched wheelbase is the key here, and Honda has also increased rear headroom, even though the roof is a smidge lower. This was achieved by lowering the seating positions slightly, and the car’s center of gravity along with them. All good.

The new infotainment and safety features that made their debut with the sedan carry forward to the coupe. Of the latter, the lane departure warning and assist could use some work. Based on our experience with pre-production cars, it seems a little inconsistent in identifying edge and center lines on the pavement, and a little too eager to intervene when it does see them.
Fortunately, the system can be turned off.

The Verdict:

If you're considering the 2016 Honda Civic Coupe, you may be wondering how much it will cost. Well, Honda isn't releasing price information until just before the coupe goes on sale in mid-March. We do know that pricing for the new sedan, with the same five trim levels—LX, LX-P, EXT, EXT-L (the L stands for leather), and the new top-of-the-line Touring—ranges from $19,475 to $27,435. So as a pure estimate, add $250 to each increment.

At the top of the range, that begins to feel a little pricey. But the compact coupe market is very sparse, and compared to its three key competitors—Subaru BR-Z and the former Scion, now Toyota, FR-S and tC—the Civic holds the edge in sophistication, refinement, and roominess.

Coupes obviously aren’t for everyone. The number of choices at the compact end of the market make this clear; it’s just not much of a market. But for affordable performance, comfort, and style, the new Civic is tops.

title: My Car Doesn't Understand Me
subTitle: J.D. Power study shows you're not the only one who can't get voice recognition to recognize you.

pageElements.text: Technology is great, isn't it? Don't you love being able to tell your smartphone, or your car's infotainment screen, "Directions to nearest pharmacy," and get a snappy answer with turn-by-turn directions?

Unfortunately, your phone is far more likely to be on your wavelength than your car. The venerable J.D. Power U.S. Vehicle Dependability Study bears that out, with the 2016 report, released today, revealing that failure to communicate is frustrating a lot of car buyers.

The J.D. Power study rankings are based on the number of problems reported in the past twelve months among owners of 2013 model vehicles bought new. Lexus was in first place this year, with 95 problems reported per 100 vehicles. Rounding out the top five were Porsche (97), Buick (106), Toyota (113), and GMC (120). The bottom five were Jeep (181), Land Rover (198), Smart (199), Ford (204), and Dodge (208). Here's the full ranking by make.
Bluetooth pairing and connectivity are the top complaint, along with misinterpretation of your instructions when you use the built-in voice recognition.

Bluetooth pairing and connectivity are the number-one complaint about a new car's technology these days, along with the misinterpretation of your instructions when you use the built-in voice recognition. Trouble navigating the car's nav system is right up there, too. In fact 20 percent of all problems reported in the J.D. Power study were with the in-vehicle communication.
While it may be better than having your engine die at 1,500 miles, it's so annoying that it eats into the joy of having the technology in the first place. Do you have this problem?
For some reason, I don't. But the same is not true of JKC colleagues Jean Jennings and Molly Jean.

Jean has this cautionary tale: "My lawyer moved his business several years ago, but the nav system in my test car kept sending me 20 miles away, to his old address. Despite the map pin on the screen dropped on his new address. In many new cars, voice recognition is a crap shoot. It is amazing how many aren't even close to whom you requested. Not even any matching syllables or even consonants. I decided it's my nasally Midwest accent. I need a voice model, or translator."

Meanwhile, Molly says: "I think there is something about my voice that defies recognition by a computer. Last week I was trying to call my husband, Tom Gallagher, in the BMW 340i xDrive. The car asked me if I wanted Elle Gallagher (my daughter). I said no. I made a second attempt. It asked if I wanted Cathy Gallagher. I said no. It then connected me to Cathy."
There's a more ominous side to this problem, and it's not that your nav will take you to Genoa, Italy, when you're trying to go to Geneva, Switzerland. It's trust.

There's a more ominous side to this problem, and it's not that your nav system will take you to Genoa, Italy, when you're trying to go to Geneva, Switzerland (although that could conceivably happen if you weren't paying attention). It's trust. As J.D. Power U.S. automotive vice-president Renee Stephens noted: “Right now, if consumers can’t rely on their vehicle to connect to their smartphone, or have faith that their navigation system will route them to their destination, they’re certainly not yet ready to trust that autonomous technology will keep their vehicle out of the ditch.”
We have a few suggestions. Try these and see if your personal customer satisfaction gets any higher.

1. Be thoughtful about the way you enter contact names in your phone book. Ford's Sync system suggests that you enter both first and last names to help the system choose the right person. Maybe you want to give a more detailed contact name for those you will be using frequently: "Tom My Husband" would narrow it down for Molly.

2. Read your owner's manual or look at owner information online. Maybe there's some protocol you can follow with your voice commands to improve chances of success. Ford's owner site explains that, for its Sync system, there's a particular order you need to give information in. You need to say "Climate" before giving climate commands, for example. Volvo notes that you can't talk to the system while the system is talking to you; it can't listen and talk at the same time.

3. Expect there to be a learning curve. We have all been spoiled by Siri on the iPhone, who can chat us up as well as a human, even chiding us more politely than any human when we lose our tempers. Jean's Siri responded to a sample testy remark with "After all I've done for you?" while my Siri, subjected to profane language as a test, responded, "I'll pretend I didn't hear that." Your car just might not be up to speed for such an instant relationship. The in-car systems are intuitive, but that doesn't mean you can just start the car and immediately understand how it all works. Be gentle with it and speak slowly and deliberately. You'll come to understand what its shortcomings are over time.

The Lexus owner site suggests "spending an hour or so in the car, stationary in your driveway, listening to [the car's] audio tutorials and practicing using voice commands...at the end, you should have a pretty solid foundation for using one of your vehicle’s more intriguing technologies." Follow that wise advice, and you, like Lexus, might find yourself at the low end of the problem-reporting scale.

title: Drowsiness Detection Systems
subTitle: Wake up and smell the coffee.
promoTeaserSmall: Do carmakers have to draw you a picture of a cup of coffee to get you to take a break when you're sleepy? Apparently so.
promoTeaser: Do carmakers have to draw you a picture of a cup of coffee to get you to take a break when you're sleepy? Apparently so.

metaDescription: Drowsiness Detection Systems: Jean Knows Cars runs down the list of driver alert systems to keep drowsy drivers from getting into an accident.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text:
If you sometimes find yourself rolling the window down to stay awake on long drives, you're not alone. In 2009, an estimated 30,000 injury crashes involved drowsy drivers, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. But some of those crashes may soon be able to be averted, thanks to new technologies that address drowsy driving. It's one of a host of new active safety alerts that are now appearing on cars. After extensive time researching the best way to diagnose and address drowsy driving, several automakers are starting to roll out systems intended to let you know when you should take a break. While these are starting out on high-end models, they're expected to filter down to more mainstream vehicles in the coming years. 
	
  Here's a glimpse at the various systems intended to address drowsy driving.

images.caption: Great minds think alike: Lincoln's drowsiness alert system.
Volvo's system is categorical.
Mercedes-Benz asks politely.

pageElements.text:
Volvo

Volvo was the first to market with a system. Its Driver Alert Control appeared on the 2008 S80, XC70, and V70. It's now offered as a part of a technology package option of $2,100 on the 2013 S60, S80, XC60, and XC70.Volvo uses a camera mounted behind the rear-view mirror that looks at road markings, along with a combination of inputs including steering movements and use of the accelerator and brake pedals to determine drowsiness. A set of five bars, similar to those indicating cell phone reception, appear in the dashboard. When those bars diminish to two, drivers will hear an audible chime, similar but lower in volume to a door chime, and will get a written warning in the instrument panel that says "time for a break" along with a coffee cup. Volvo was aiming for a more "gentle" sound that wouldn't scare and alarm the driver, which could cause an abrupt reaction in driving, said Adam Kopstein, who manages the North American Safety Office of Volvo Cars North America. He says the system is helping Volvo to achieve its ambitious long-term goal of designing a vehicle that doesn't crash.

Mercedes-Benz

Mercedes rolled out drowsiness detection in 2009, in the 2010 E-Class. Its "Attention Assist" creates a driver profile within 20 minutes of driving, which forms the baseline in determining how the driver operates the vehicle. The system uses a steering sensor, along with software that tracks 70 inputs, including such details as where the vehicle is in the lane, how often the driver adjusts the radio controls and moves the steering wheel, and how long they've been driving. The algorithm constantly compares how the driver performs to the baseline to decide when to set off the alert. When the system identifies erratic steering corrections attributable to drowsy driving, it triggers an audible warning and a "Time for a Rest" message with a coffee cup on the instrument panel. The system is standard on all 2013 C-, CL-, E-, GL-, GLK-, M-, S-, SL-, and SLK-Class vehicles. Kaity Aurilio, assistant product manager of infotainment and safety technology strategy at Mercedes-Benz USA, said the inputs were gathered through 10,000 hours of testing on driver simulators by 640 students in Germany, which identified the key indicators of fatigue.

Ford Motor Company

Ford's "Driver Alert" is packaged with a lane keeping system and is offered on the 2013 Fusion and Explorer Limited as well as the 2013 Lincoln MKS and MKT. It's also in the 2013 MKZ. It's offered as part of a $1,000 driver assist option on the Fusion and a $4,600 Lincoln technology package option that includes several high-tech features. It uses a forward-facing camera mounted behind the rear view mirror that tracks the lane lines. Driver Alert uses an algorithm to determine how much you're weaving and has five different vigilance levels. If you get to the fifth one, an alert will pop up on the instrument cluster that says "rest suggested" along with a coffee cup icon. If the driver continues the same pattern of erratic driving, a secondary warning says "rest recommended" with the coffee cup. Ford decided to package this with its lane keeping alert and lane keeping aid system because it uses the same sensor. Extensive testing of drivers who went without sleep for 24 hours and then used a driving simulator demonstrated that "erratic driving in and out of a lane was the most robust indicator of drowsiness," said Jeff Greenberg, Ford's senior technical leader of research and advanced engineering. He says Ford decided to go with a suggestion for rest because NHTSA found only two strategies that effectively addressed drowsiness: caffeine and a nap of 20 minutes or more. "We can't advise you to take a nap but we can advise you to take a break," he said. Ford nixed an audible alarm, since "there is enough beeping at you in the car," he said.

BMW of North America

BMW offers "Attention Assistant" as standard on its 2013 7 Series. The system operates similarly to the others on the market, measuring a variety of driver inputs, such as steering, on an ongoing basis looking for deviations. When a pattern is detected, it offers an audible tone, along with the words, "Break Recommended" in the display.

Automakers have experimented with a variety of ways to wake up drowsy drivers, including emitting an aroma through the dashboard. But that ultimately has yet to be used. Paul Green, Research Professor with the University of  Michigan Transportation Research Institute Driver Interface Group, says the drawback of aromas is that it takes time to dispense them and controlling their delivery to the driver and others is not easy.

Eye movement was one of the original ways to detect drowsiness, and it's being used as a measure in a system being developed by automotive supplier Denso International America, Inc. -- and yet to appear on cars -- which has adopted facial expression as the drowsiness index. Using a camera located on the dashboard, it monitors percentage of eye closure time and heart rate, along with lane deviation. Greenberg says though the scientific basis of eye closure systems is very sound, "technically and practically being able to implement that and accurately focus the camera on the driver's eye to yield an appropriate calculation is quite challenging." He says there are also issues with older drivers who have droopy eyelids, where it's tough to get a clear picture of the eye.

The technology that most suppliers and automakers are developing is based on lane tracking, not monitoring the driver's face, said David Zuby, chief research officer at the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. He says "the jury is still out" on whether these systems are making roads safer. He says while the warning may help drivers recognize they're tired before they're aware of it, "in most cases, people will ignore the suggestion because they know they're tired, but just want to get home," instead of stopping to take a rest.

pageElements.text: Technology oozes out of the Chevy Volt even before you open the car door. Thanks to the Remote Start feature, your extended range electric vehicle can be ready and waiting for you with the cabin temperature already acclimated to the weather. Using remote start function on the Volt’s smartphone app or your key fob, you can warm up the vehicle 10 minutes before you need to leave the house. The vehicle will automatically heat the cabin climate if it’s cold outside or cool it down on hot days using your last temperature settings. This means you won’t have to shiver on chilly early mornings or sweat through your silk blouse on sweltering afternoons--at least not in your car. You can also configure the Volt’s preferences using the in-dash display to have the heated seats turn on whenever you use remote start to ensure toasty buns on the way to the office.

Besides the benefit of a smooth transition to a cozy car environment, you may also be saving energy. Preconditioning your cabin temperature while your car is still plugged into a charging station means you won’t blast the air conditioning or hot air the second you hit the road, which is like throwing money down the drain. Using AC and heat draws a lot of electricity from the lithium-ion battery, which could better be used to propel the car another few miles. And the longer you go using all electricity means fewer trips to the gas station and more dollars in your wallet.
$39,145. Remote start comes standard on the Volt.

pageElements.text: Automakers have found a new tool in the never-ending quest for better fuel economy, and it's not what you might expect. Without replacing our beloved powerful engines for more sedate options or hacking hundreds of pounds off the car's frame, Ford and Dodge have introduced a new technology that can improve fuel economy by around ten percent, according to Ford.

Debuted in the 2012 Ford Focus, active grille shutters are a small change that can make a significant difference. The shutters are a guillotine-like design that live behind the front grille and slide shut automatically at cruising speeds to help air glide over the hood of the car. This improves aerodynamics, which in turn improves gas mileage, without making any visible changes to the car. The shutters automatically open to allow air to flow when the engine needs to be cooled, usually during low-speed, stop and go traffic.

The grille shutters made their first appearance in the Ford Focus, and have since spread to the Taurus and Escape EcoBoost. Ford plans to continue rolling out the active grille across its lineup. Dodge has also started offering the technology in its Dart and Ram models.

pageElements.text: Have you ever fumbled around in the dark trying to buckle a child or elderly parent into the back seat? Mercedes-Benz has come up with a relatively simple idea to put an end to that. It will introduce an "active seatbelt buckle" on one of its luxury models by the end of the year. The high-tech buckle lights up and has an electric motor that allows it to extend out from the seat or retract into it. The buckle emerges from the upholstery by almost three inches when the rear doors are opened.

The German automaker says the new seatbelt buckle is designed to increase the percentage of rear passengers who buckle up. It also helps to hold rear passengers more firmly into place in sideways and lengthwise directions.
No word yet on what this will add to a car's bottom line or exactly which Mercedes-Benz model will be the first to get the active seatbelt buckle.

Automakers have been paying more attention to rear-seat passengers, who have sometimes been called "second-class citizens" when it comes to the newest safety features. Ford introduced inflatable rear seatbelts in 2009, and they are now available on such mainstream vehicles as the Ford Explorer.

pageElements.text: In case you aren’t an ardent car aficionado, Chrysler (and hence, Dodge) is now part of the Fiat family. Why bring this up? Because the 2013 Dodge Dart is the first new vehicle developed under Fiat’s stewardship for any of its new family of American brands, and not only does it fill a gaping hole in the Dodge lineup, it does so with real swagger. Despite being half Italian, the Dart exudes plenty of American style. Its proportions are European, but its unbroken strip of LED taillights spanning the trunk, à la the Charger, as well as the aggressive headlamp and grille treatment, are purely American. A choice of three four-cylinder engines (ranging from 160 to 184 horsepower) and three transmissions (including a conventional manual) furnish the engine bay, any combination of which should help keep one’s fuel bill manageable, though no Dart iteration achieves the magic 40 mpg fuel economy figure that has become the gold standard among compact cars. Inside the Dart, its somewhat 1990s-esque architecture detracts little from its generally pleasant ambience, and its calling cards include its availability in many flavors, each with smart ergonomics, and a huge back seat. Prices for its five available trim levels, which start under $17K and run into above $23K for the performance-oriented R/T model, are competitive compared to other compact cars. Then again, that’s darn cheap compared to most Italian automobiles.

The Cube choices are somewhat limited for the new model year, with Nissan deleting the Cube 1.8 base model, Cube 1.8 S Indigo Limited Edition and the Cube Cargo Version. More airbags than you can count and electronic Stability Control come standard, and the R8 has specially constructed crumple zones to protect passengers in the event of a collision. The interior is small, but two passengers can be quite comfortable in their leather sport seats. Drivers can choose between a coupe, an ultra-limited run Spyder, and a convertible. pageElements.text: Once upon a time, there was a plus-size, three-row SUV called the Dodge Durango, which lived in harmony with virtually no enemies. Then came a slew of three-row crossovers from its competitors, and the Durango had no choice but to evolve. Evolve it did, and after becoming a crossover itself two years ago, people liked it. The Durango has found many happy homes ever since. It is more powerful and more capable, thanks to a strong 290- to 295-horsepower V-6 (depending on model) and an even stronger available 360-horsepower Hemi V-8. Like its predecessor, it comes with rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive, but unlike before, today’s Durango is smooth and stable on the road, not bumpy and tippy. It has more usable space in its refined interior, seating six or seven people, with thirty storage spaces and, with the seats folded, room for a six-foot couch. And of course, it is dashingly good-looking. Since it's available in base SXT, nicely equipped Crew, sporty Hemi-powered R/T, and formal Citadel trim levels, selecting a Durango may be somewhat hard. That's especially true because of the newly available Rallye Appearance group that helps the SXT models look like an R/T, and the Premium Leather package that brings red-stitched, super-soft leather to the R/T. If there are bones to pick, it’s that fuel economy is less than amazing, and prices can creep pretty high with all the option boxes checked. That said, 2013 prices have dropped for some models will help this automotive fairy tale keep its happy ending.

pageElements.text: Dodge has been on a journey lately, and one particularly sad episode of its journey is, well, the Journey. A three-row, up-to-seven-passenger crossover made from the rib of the chunky, plasticky Avenger sedan back in 2007, the Journey didn’t stand a chance from the beginning. A thorough revamp, however, in 2011 brought with it tidier handling and a vastly improved interior, including one particularly cool white-on-black upholstery treatment offset by orange stitching. What the Journey did not get was dramatically different styling, which would have helped it lure people away from more established crossovers like the Ford Edge, Honda Crosstour, and Hyundai Santa Fe, to name a few. And so the Journey continues to struggle in spite of Dodge having groomed it into a reasonably nice tall wagon/small minivan. It is available in five trim levels, with top-tier Crew and R/T models (the latter being the “sporty” one) offering a legitimately luxurious driving experience. The steering is communicative, and the thrust from the available 283-horsepower V-6 is outstanding, even with optional all-wheel drive. And we love how its second-row under-floor bins hold chilled soda cans or muddy shoes. Best of all, it is one of the most aggressively priced crossovers around, with most 2013 trim levels priced lower than in 2012, starting at under $20,000 for the AVP and the range-topping R/T model starting at just under $30K. Is that enough to get consumers’ attention this year? Probably not, but it is a respectable value for those who notice.

pageElements.text: The refined Infiniti QX is a full-size luxury SUV that was redesigned for 2011 to make it look more like the brand’s smaller cohorts. It pulls off the difficult trick of being cushy and rugged all at once – but it is better at hauling people than cargo. Ride and handling are improved since the QX has been designed as an SUV rather than being built off a modified pickup-truck platform. Still, the QX’s snow and tow modes made it a valiant performer in bad weather and boat transportation. It can haul up to 8,500 pounds. Buyers should be prepared to shell out major bucks at the gas pump. Both the rear- and four-wheel drive versions of the QX return only 14 mpg in city driving and 20 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The standard 5.6-liter V-8 engine has direct fuel injection and makes 400 horsepower. It is linked to a seven-speed automatic transmission. The enormous SUV can seat up to eight in three rows of leather-lined luxury. Check the box for the no-cost split bench seat if you need room for eight. While 2013 pricing has yet to be announced, expect to pay over $60,000 for the biggest SUV in the Infiniti lineup. The Azera is equipped with a 293-horsepower direct-injection 3.3-liter V-6 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. Gas mileage is good at 20 mpg in the city and 30 on the highway, but not as good as some of Azera’s key domestic competitors, including the 2013 Ford Taurus. The Azera has been criticized for its artificial steering feel, some visibility issues, and some cabin trim that may not feel quite as luxurious as it should. But it’s become a solid choice for shoppers who need a large sedan and don’t want to pay a fortune for a deluxe look and lots of standard equipment. The Azera is no longer a Lexus wannabe. contributors.displayName: Jean Jennings, President and Editor in Chief
contributors.bio:
Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. At the age of eighteen, she bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

pageElements.text: Highest among the many reasons I love cars are (1) the amazing places they have taken me, and (2) the great characters I’ve met along the way. The highlight of my 2012 was traveling to Austin, Texas, last spring to hang out with the heavily tattooed VooDoo Dolls car club at the Lonestar Rod & Kustom Roundup, a two-day car show and music festival sponsored by Austin’s famous Continental Club.

I don’t have tattoos, not that I haven’t had random thoughts over the years about what I would have inked on an arm if the spirit moved me. “Tim Is Gone,” my husband, Tim, has suggested. I find that hilarious.

But I’ve had old cars and worked on them at a time when young girls didn’t, and when the guys I hung out with didn’t, either. Not that there weren’t any. There were plenty. It’s just that, back then, I didn’t know where the other girls were, you know?

I saw the Dolls a year ago on a documentary celebrating Chevrolet’s centennial, talking about their all-girls car club and their love of cars. How cool! And it didn’t hurt that they were such characters, with their humorous neon green logo, their tattoos, and their bigger-than-life personalities shining through the screen. 
Here are the girls I wish I’d known when I was growing up:

—Peggy Ellis, 37, is one of Austin’s more interesting registered dental assistants when you consider the one-and-three-quarter-inch ear plugs stretching her lobes nearly to her shoulders and the riotous canvas of inked images poking out of her tank top and snaking down her legs below denim cutoffs. They are old school charming, and she proudly cites the famous artists who’ve worked on her. As far as I can tell, there’s not a lot of room left.

Peggy founded the VooDoo Dolls CC in 2006 with four friends, of whom two (Marcee Ribeiro and Jane Johnson) are still active members. 
“The club was started in March 2006 after we’d all met and gone to car events together,” Peggy recounts. “We decided we were tired of tagging along with the guys, so we started a car club of our own. Our motto has always been, “We like grease on more than just our pillowcases.” That cracks her up.

“We owe a lot to the clubs that came before us. The BelleFlowers. The Pink Slips. The Pedal Pushers. We spent five days saying no one wanted to be wearing pink. Mike Adair, a tattoo artist, drew our logo.
“With thanks to the club, we have all become eager to learn our way around our cars as well as other cars,” she says. “We all have and do work on the cars that we own.”

—Marcee Ribeiro, 37, has jet black hair, bright red lips, and short shorts and alternates between cowgirl and motorcycle boots. She owns a 1958 Chevy Bel Air that is photo-realistically tattooed on her right thigh, just below another tattoo, of her mother. “This is Mary L., my mom,” she tells me. “She was a special ed teacher. And this is her car. My mom hated my tattoos, but she would have liked this one.

“She took her driving test in a 1958 Bel Air, and she told my dad about it. My dad builds cars, and he found a 1958 Bel Air in a pasture one night. He stopped and asked the farmer how much, the farmer told him $150, and my dad paid him and went back the next day. That’s when he saw that the whole front end was wrecked. But he didn’t care, because my mom wanted it.

“It took him seven or eight years to rebuild it to show condition. My mom was so proud of it. They let me drive it to prom, and I got a flat tire. I jacked it up on the body instead of the frame. My dad took the keys and told me I could never drive it again. When my mom passed, he gave it to me. He helps me work on it. Recently, he was doing a tuneup and asked me if I had the owner’s manual. ‘I need to set the firing order [of the spark plugs],’ he said. ‘Well, Daddy, I wrote that down from last time,’ I told him. ‘You wrote it down? You have it?’ ‘Yeah, Daddy, I kept it.’ ‘Well, goddamn!’ he said.

“What I really want is one of those Trophy Queen purses, but it costs $350, and I really need a new motor. My daddy isn’t normally sweet, but he said, ‘Sit down, honey. Now sweetie, there’s nothing more I can do. That motor is shot.’ I feel like I’ve been working on that car all my life,” she sighs. “Still, the more you know, the easier you find out it is. Hell, baking is harder than working on cars.”

—Jane Johnson, 28, another of the VooDoo Dolls co-founders, works on the Whole Foods website at its Austin headquarters. Her tattoos are an altogether different style, in the manner of Mexican candle saints, only with an automotive theme. Look closely, and you’ll see butterflies filled with pistons and wrenches. Our Lady of Guadalupe is standing piously amid spark plugs and burning rubber on Jane’s right outer thigh. "Nothing does more for my spirit than the Dolls,” says Jane.

—Vanessa Calovich, 29, is a Kansas farm girl who has been a member of the Dolls since she was twenty-four, is the acknowledged mechanic of the group, and has a tattoo of Robert Mitchum’s head on her left thigh. Robert Mitchum as he appeared in the 1958 movie Thunder Road, to be exact.

“Excuse me,” I ask her. “Is that Robert Mitchum tattooed on your thigh?”
She says, “Yeah, dude, this is gonna be my thigh of dead men I’d like to meet.”

“Who else is gonna be on it?” I ask.
“Steve McQueen, Paul Newman, and Gene Wilder,” she replies.
“Gene Wilder?!?” we all shout at once and burst out laughing. Especially because Gene Wilder is not even dead yet.
“Dude,” she answers, with great seriousness. “Gene Wilder’s hot!”
—Nicole Soumbeniotis, 35, has been a member since 2008.

“Let me spell that for you.” She spells her name twice, and then she writes it down. I can proudly say that I just typed it from memory. Nicole has a car, but it currently resides in another state, which doesn’t slow her down. She’s hanging with the girls, wearing full lime green on black VooDoo Dolls regalia. (You know how JKC loves that lime green.)

—Nikki Lange, 40, joined in 2010. She’s the newest and oldest member of the Dolls. She works for the city of Austin, but don’t let that give you the wrong idea about her. “San Diego is my hometown. I moved to Austin in 2006, following my ex-husband. He lost me, the dog, the house, and the hot rod.

“Before I got divorced, all my tats were on my upper arms. My favorite tattoo is ‘Cruisin’ Is Not a Crime.’ I wanted to do that first, but it was so boyish, I did a heart on my back instead. I wanted to place ‘Cruisin’ Is Not a Crime’ very carefully where people couldn’t see it unless I wanted them to. So it’s on the inside of my left upper arm. It’s my favorite tattoo, and I placed it so I could see it in my rear-view mirror.

“After the divorce, I thought, is the tattoo culture part of before, or is this going to be me on my own? I knew the girls and they were my support. My tattoos are a sign of my independence, and I was way late to the scene. They don’t mean anything deep. I just like them.”

Being a member of the Dolls also gave Lange a reason to keep her hot rod truck. “I learned how to work on my truck using Auto Mechanics for Dummies. I take a photo of everything, how it looks before I take it out.”

The Dolls were up all night Wednesday baking desserts (for 500!) for the traditional Thursday night Meatheads car club barbecue to welcome the hot rodders pouring into town for the Lonestar Roundup. “We took the baked goods over in a new car because we didn’t want them to taste like gas,” said Peggy. And then they partied all night Thursday. Pure adrenaline, copious amounts of Lone Star beer, and dancing to the local Texas swing and country music like the LeRoi Brothers blasting from the stage kept them going all day Friday. There were tattoo artist friends and hot rod legends for Peggy to visit. There were minibike races in the rodeo ring for Vanessa to flag off, and a display of the coveted Trophy Queen purses in the surprisingly jammed barn of cool Fifties-era clothing for Marcee and Nikki to cruise.

The VooDoo Dolls turned in early and came back for more on Saturday, gearing up for their heroine Wanda Jackson, the Queen of Rockabilly, to hit the stage late afternoon. Then they packed up the circus and prepared to move it to town, with parties at Austin’s numerous speed shops and a killer evening of cruising Congress Avenue.

“Sunday, we have Chickenshit Bingo with Dale Watson at Ginny’s Little Longhorn,” said Marcy. “Everyone sits around waiting for the chicken to shit and hoping it shits on their number, while Dale Watson is playing and singing about Lone Star beer.”

Sadly, I was going to have to miss that. Devastated, I gathered with them on Saturday night for one last Lone Star to talk about the tattoos, the cars, and mostly the bond these women have for each other.
Nicole Soumbeniotis: “I love everything about the club.”
Jane Johnson: “Nothing does more for my spirit than the Dolls.”
Peggy Ellis: “Everything is loud and fast and go-go-go.”
Marcee Ribeiro: “It’s family.”
Nikki Lange: “It’s just badass. It’s my power suit.”

pageElements.text: The Mazda 2 has a lot to recommend it, from its long list of standard and safety features, to its decent cabin and cute looks. But the subcompact delivers low fuel economy for such a small car – and doesn’t even hit the magic 40-mpg mark in highway driving. The Mazda 2 also has a steep base price for such a small car, with the base 2013 Sport model starting at over $15,000. An uplevel Mazda 2 Touring model tops $17,000. On the plus side, the Mazda 2 enters the post-modern world with a new USB port, something it lacked in the past. Its refined four-cylinder engine feels livelier than its 100-horsepower rating would suggest, especially when it’s linked to the five-speed manual transmission. A four-speed automatic transmission is optional. There’s no denying that the five-seater is a fun-to-drive city car, but there may be too many compromises for some. The Mazda 2 has a tight back seat and limited cargo room. It lacks the luxury features available in newer subcompacts like the Ford Fiesta. That means no navigation system or heated seats. The Touring model is the way to go if you’re looking for amenities. It includes fifteen-inch alloy wheels, a rear spoiler, chrome exhaust tips, cruise control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and an audio system with six speakers. The main problem with the Mazda 2 occurs once comparison shopping begins. When you stack it up against its sizeable competition, it’s merely average.

pageElements.text: Destined to make it onto more bedroom walls of adolescent boys than any American car, save perhaps the Chevrolet Corvette, is the all-new SRT Viper. Still a monstrously powerful supercar but slightly less obnoxious than the wily Vipers of yore, the 2013 Viper shed its fiberglass skin in favor of more elegant, organically shaped carbon fiber and aluminum body panels that save weight while allow for far more consistent body gaps. The Viper also shed the Dodge brand name in favor of Chrysler’s Street and Racing Technology—a.k.a. SRT—brand name. Base Vipers gain infinitely more refined interiors with a customizable instrument screen and far more creature comforts (and alas, the floorboards will no longer melt your tennis shoes). The even sharper-edged (and $23,000 more expensive!) GTS model receives additional leather trim, an adjustable suspension, upgraded brakes and more. The re-imagined exterior lighting includes LED running lamps and taillamps, but the overall look is pure Viper, including the double-bubble roof (ostensibly for helmet clearance). An 8.4-liter V-10 still resides under the hood, this time with new fewer than 640 horsepower (not sure how much that is in snakepower, but it’s certainly a lot). Missing from the lineup at this point is a roadster model; the 2013 model year appears to be for coupes only. Don’t expect Dodge—er, SRT—to stay out of the convertible business for long, though. After all, Viper drivers, of all people, love to be seen.

pageElements.text: The spacious six-seater Impala sedan has been a stalwart in its segment for half a century. This year is the last for the current model, since Chevrolet has completely redesigned the Impala for 2014. That will present buyers of full-size sedans with a sleeker, much more modern-looking product. In the meantime, the current Impala will stick around in its current guise for 2013. Part of its appeal this year will be a Luxury Edition package that includes heated leather front seats, a premium Bose audio system with eight speakers, a universal home remote control, and other quality-of-life features. The uplevel LT and LTZ models will be available in a new Crystal Red Tintcoat color to help the old Impala go out with a flourish. The 2013 Impala comes with a 3.6-liter V-6 that makes 300 horsepower, coupled to a six-speed automatic transmission. Despite its old-school size and shape, this sedan gets up to 30 mpg on the highway. The upcoming 2014 model will be available with a choice of three new engines, two four-cylinders (one of which is a mild hybrid) and a V-6, to go with its new look. It’s scheduled to come out in early 2013. The Chevrolet Impala may not get anybody’s heart racing, but it fills the bill just fine if what you want is a traditional big sedan. Get a good deal on the 2013, or look forward to the upcoming 2014? Decisions, decisions.

pageElements.text: Not many people can say they learned to drive a manual-transmission car in one of the world’s most beautiful and exotic locales—but I can. I was twenty-three years old and had only gotten my driver’s license the previous year, after putting it off on the grounds that I was a hippie and had no car anyway.

In the early 1980s, I found myself in France, where cars with stick shifts were the rule rather than the exception. Still: no car, no problem. But then came the trip where I hitchhiked with a non-driving friend from northeast France down to Nice and got on a ferry to a place where a car was indispensable: the island of Corsica.

If you’ve never thought much about the island of Corsica except a vague recollection that Napoleon was from there, you’ve missed something in life. A.k.a. “the scented isle,” Corsica is a jewel. It lolls in the Mediterranean, south of France—to which it belongs—just north of Sardinia and west of Sicily.

I had phoned ahead in this pre-e-mail time and reserved an automatic-transmission car from the Hertz agency in Bastia, on the island’s northern tip. We had in mind spending three days driving all the way around the entire island near the shore. You can pretty much do that the whole way on the small routes nationales, and I recommend it.

Just as an interesting bit of trivia, there were serious issues with terrorist activity at the time: a liberation movement to cut Corsica loose from France was in full swing, bombings at tourist resorts around the island were happening, that sort of thing.

Full of American-tourist confidence, I walked in to the Hertz office, only to be told that there were no cars available with automatic transmissions. Indeed, the rental agent seemed not to understand that such a car existed. I explained my ignorance of stick-shift usage, and she rolled her eyes, then came out from behind the desk, swinging a car key, and invited me to follow her.

Out on the street stood a Citroen LNA. I eyed it warily. She bundled me into it, sat in the passenger’s seat, and proceeded to talk me through the process of driving it. Luckily I had been in France long enough to understand the language, but there was a definite mechanical intelligence barrier. After a few turns around the block, somehow she satisfied herself that I had the basic idea—I don’t know how, since I stalled every time I lifted my clumsy left foot off the clutch. She washed her hands of me and returned to the office, and the car was ours for the weekend.
It seemed to take nine hours to get out of Bastia. Old men were coming out of cafes to point and stare.

I will never, ever forget the feeling of driving that car out of town at rush hour on a Friday afternoon. I stalled, gunned the engine, and made that minicar dance like water on a hot griddle, over and over again. It seemed to take nine hours to get out of Bastia. Old men were coming out of cafes to point and stare. Teens on motorbikes roared past, making rude remarks such as “Ouais, elle sait meme pas conduire sa bagnole, eh!” (she doesn’t even know how to drive her car). Meanwhile, on every corner stood an armed police officer, placed there to strike fear in the hearts of bombers, I guess, but they weren’t pulling off the tough act so well, since they were doubled over laughing at me.

Getting out into the countryside had its own challenges. It was essential to sound the car horn when going around one of the many blind curves, since there might be a car coming the other way. More important, there might be sheep. And there often were—hundreds of them, milling around in the middle of the road. They usually looked up at our approaching car with mild indifference, but eventually they would move.

Over the course of the weekend, I learned a lot about driving. On stretches of unpopulated road between villages, I was able to work out the gentle balance of lifting the left foot as I depressed the right, moving up through the gears with increasing confidence. I’m not saying I became a great stick-shift driver, but before long I reached the point of comfort, and then of unconscious competence.

I couldn’t wait to get back to the Hertz office and triumphantly hand the keys to the rental clerk, proclaiming success. Unfortunately, the office was closed on Monday afternoons, so my great adventure ended with the anticlimax of dropping the keys through a slot. In my heart, though, I knew I had won. Plus, I liked it. My first new car, purchased four years later, had a manual transmission.

images.caption: Bastia, at Corsica's northern tip, where I picked up the car.

pageElements.text:
Is this a necessary skill?

My friend Julie has always driven manual-transmission Subarus. Years ago, she was far out in the country, late at night, with a passenger who didn’t know how to drive a stick shift. A rabbit ran out in front of her car, and she couldn’t avoid it, and it was killed. She was so distraught that she couldn’t continue driving. The passenger couldn’t drive a stick, so there they sat half the night until Julie was calm enough to drive again. It occurred to me: what if there had been some other kind of emergency? Thinking about that should convince anyone to acquire this essential driving skill. Plus, it’s fun once you get the hang of it!

I’ll tell you one thing: my own kids are going to learn how to drive a stick shift--but definitely from a qualified instructor, not the way I did. In fact, if they could arrange to do hardly any of the crazy things I did at their age, that would be great.

Feedback wanted!

What about you? Do you know how to drive a manual-transmission car? Have you always wanted to? Have you tried and given up? We want to hear all the details. Please Comment below.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s no secret that sending a new driver out on the road alone in a multi-thousand-pound missile is nerve-racking for the parents of teenagers, to say the least. Luckily, automakers are coming up with ways to ease the minds of nervous parents.

Ford’s MyKey technology, originally used in fleet vehicles to allow fleet owners a measure of control over their drivers, is now available with all vehicles that have Sync. MyKey allows a car owner to put limits on one of a vehicle’s keys, presumably the ones that belong to the teen driver. The limits can include a Persistent Ford Belt Minder, which will remind drivers to buckle up by sounding a chime at regular intervals and muting audio, an electronically limited top speed of 80 mph, and an early low fuel warning (at seventy-five miles instead of fifty miles until empty) to help absent-minded teens avoid being stranded.

Mercedes-Benz takes the limitations even further by allowing owners who drive cars equipped with mbrace2 to track their car’s movements, using what the automaker calls a "breadcrumb" method, via a dedicated mbrace website. Once logged in, owners can use the mbrace website to set their preferences to record what Mercedes-Benz calls a Driving Journal, which essentially directs the car to record its trip history, then makes that history viewable online. Through the mbrace website, owners can also set up zones on a map that they don’t want the car to enter – say, a bad neighborhood or your daughter’s boyfriend’s house. You can choose to be alerted when a car enters or exits the zones you have chosen. Owners can also choose to receive alerts when the car exceeds a certain speed or is started after curfew.

If you value serenity, it might be worth limiting the number of alerts you choose to receive from your Mercedes. It wouldn't be surprising if a teen driving a car with that many limitations were to break a rule about once every five minutes.

Perhaps the most revelatory thing about these technologies is the way that new drivers react to them. According to Ford, a poll of young drivers said that 67 percent of them initially disliked MyKey’s features – no shock there – but when paired with the idea that they would be allowed more access to a car, 64 percent were “more accepting” of the technology.

MyKey is standard equipment on almost all Ford and Lincoln vehicles. Mercedes-Benz's mbrace2 is a subscription service, available on all 2013 Mercedes-Benz models except the S- and CL-Class. The service costs $280 per year after a six-month free trial, with up to $28 in extra costs per month depending on the features you choose.

pageElements.text: What if you could take the hundreds of hours per year that the average American driver spends commuting, and wring the majority of the stress out of all that driving time? There just might be a way, because we’ve just learned about Volvo’s latest technological breakthrough, the Traffic Jam Assistance System.

If you have spent any amount of time commuting in heavy traffic, you know the frustration of crawling along for miles as your life ticks by, alternately slamming on the brakes and cooling your heels while traffic moves in fits and starts. Imagine, if you will, a feature that lets you relax while the car autonomously keeps you at a safe following distance in slow-moving traffic.

This is Volvo's Traffic Jam Assistance technology. It is an evolution of Volvo’s adaptive cruise control and lane keeping systems, which were rolled out on the Volvo V40 earlier this year. When the driver pushes a button, the engine, brakes, and steering respond automatically to maintain a set distance behind the vehicle ahead when traffic is moving at those frustratingly low speeds up to 31 mph.

Volvo notes that this technology is not just a way to make commuting less annoying. It also can help cut fuel consumption and improve traffic flow—which could reduce the amount of time you have to spend in a slow-moving line, so it’s all good.

Already, the Swedish automaker is looking to get government support in the United States for standardized regulation of the autonomous driving experience. Volvo R&D chief Peter Mertens spoke in Washington, D.C., earlier this week about “policy implications of autonomous vehicles” in a talk co-sponsored by the Embassy of Sweden, during which he called for research by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and eventual performance ratings on autonomous driving technology. Volvo is concerned, he said, that state-by-state regulation could restrict and discourage the smooth implementation of autonomous driving technology.

It all feels very Jetsons-like, but this is no mere concept. Volvo anticipates a 2014 rollout for the technology, although it didn’t reveal which vehicles will get it. That’s not a moment too soon for those of us who loathe crawling along in bumper-to-bumper traffic. Mertens says it’s among the first steps toward “our vision that future cars will not crash at all.”

pageElements.text: Speed limits and drivers have been at odds for as long as they have existed in the same universe. I was born much too late for Sammy Hagar’s ode to reckless driving to inform my teenage years, but I still occasionally find myself chanting “I can’t drive 55” when zooming down rural roads well above the posted speed limit. I was doing just that this summer when I was pulled over and ticketed for doing 65 in a 55-mph zone in southern Michigan. I normally don’t mind getting pulled over, because normally I know I deserve it. But something about that incident got under my skin, so I decided to get to the bottom of this whole “speed limit” thing.

In an effort to make sense of the laws I have always considered oppressive, I spent a few hours riding around in a police car with Officer Jason Kitts of the Ann Arbor Police Department, tracking down the hardened criminals who disregard traffic laws in our fair city. And now, for your convenience, I have compiled a list of the things I learned during my trip behind the veil.

You’re (Probably) Not Being Profiled
The conventional wisdom about ticket enforcement says that if you’re a young man driving a bright red sports car, or a black man blasting rap music, you’re going to get pulled over pretty much no matter what. Officer Kitts promised that the car you drive doesn’t matter to him when he pulls you over (half of the cars we pulled over that afternoon were Mazdas, but that may say more about Mazda owners than police officers): "[Car] color doesn’t matter, car type doesn’t matter, male, female, hot, not hot. Doesn’t matter. Whoever’s going faster.”

Kitts conceded that it was possible that other officers cared about such minutiae, but at least in Ann Arbor, racial profiling is not left up to chance. After every stop, Officer Kitts had to fill out a form that recorded not only the type of incident and type of citation, but the age, gender, and race of the driver as well as whether the officer knew the person’s race before pulling them over. According to Kitts, the city of Ann Arbor conducted a year-long study to determine whether members of a certain race were being targeted over others. “You know what we found? We pull over old, white people.” Which, in case you’ve never been to Ann Arbor, sounds just about right.

Quotas
Quotas are like the giant squids of the law enforcement world: we’re pretty sure they exist, but we’ve never seen one in the flesh. Michigan has a law in effect prohibiting the establishment of monthly ticket quotas, and Officer Kitts was very clear that he was not subject to meeting a quota.

When I met up with him after lunch, he had already written nine tickets that day, a number that he regarded as fairly typical. He did allow that there was an “expectation” that officers assigned to a specialty unit write 100 tickets a month and that there is a monthly review of each officer’s statistics, but said that officers who didn’t meet that mark wouldn’t face any adverse consequences. He said he felt “some” pressure to keep his numbers of tickets up, especially in relation to temporary officers on his beat. “If you come in to be a temporary officer you shouldn’t beat me,” he said. But no firm quotas. They promise.

There Really Is a Permanent Record
My high school principal was great fan of invoking the so-called “permanent record.” If he was to be believed, every detention served or class skipped would be recorded and sent to future colleges and employers, who would, of course, be horrified by my juvenile delinquency. That is not real. However, if you’ve ever been pulled over and ticketed by a police officer, even if it was a long time ago or in a different state, that will stay with you. Take it from me.

I have been pulled over for speeding eight times and received three tickets. Every one of those tickets is preserved in excruciating detail on an Internet database somewhere, a database that was accessed by Officer Kitts once he had my license number. The ticket I got in Indiana for going 87 mph on the freeway three years ago was right up top, followed by a ticket for improper lane use in East Lansing two years ago, followed by that obnoxious citation from Calhoun County this summer. Officer Kitts could also see that the probationary period on my license was extended when I was seventeen, and that I had received a letter from the Secretary of State encouraging me to take a defensive driving course. He could also see that I had taken and successfully completed said course (though he couldn’t tell that I spent every minute of it in complete mental agony). After joking about my questionable driving habits, Officer Kitts warned me: “If you get pulled over in twenty years, this will all still be here.”
Just what I was hoping for.

pageElements.text: It's a peculiarly modern dilemma for those of us who live in cold climates: how to scroll through the iPhone while wearing gloves? As for me, I spend an inordinate amount of time pulling on gloves, yanking them off, and then pulling them on again. A Canadian company, appropriately enough, has a lineup of reasonably priced gloves that solve that problem. We spotted their Slide 'Em touchscreen-friendly gloves at the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) trade show in Las Vegas.

The trick in these gloves--a brand-new product just unveiled in September--is their thin fabric over the fingertips, which contrasts with the heavy-duty sturdiness of the rest of the glove. Now that touchscreens are starting to proliferate inside cars, it's going to be more important than ever to keep those fingertips free to do the job.

The gloves come in traditional black, safety glove green, and an array of bright colors. The company says it designed them to be "detailed crazy," and to you and me that means they are decidedly wild and immediately recognizable. Depending on your fashion style, this may or may not suit you, but it will definitely suit your need to access Facebook while you're out in the cold with your phone.
They gloves are available on the Slide 'Em website starting at a reasonable $34.95.

title: '14 Fiesta Gets One-Liter Engine
promoTeaserSmall: EcoBoost engine  will make Ford Fiesta the most fuel-efficient non-hybrid/non-diesel choice.

metaTitle: '14 Fiesta Gets One-Liter Engine - JeanKnowsCars.com
