pageElements.text: When you're looking for a new car, especially these days, you probably put fuel efficiency near the top of your list. But you don't want to give up any more excitement or fun than you have to. Ford might have something for you here. Today Ford announced it's bringing U.S. shoppers a one-liter engine for the 2014 Fiesta. It's not just a small engine; it's a small, turbocharged, three-cylinder engine that's thoroughly modern and part of Ford's popular EcoBoost lineup. With this  powerplant as an option, the fun little Ford will become the most fuel-efficient car you can buy without springing for a hybrid or a diesel.

The Engine That Fit In the Carry-On Bag

The one-liter three-cylinder is the smallest member of Ford’s EcoBoost turbocharged engine lineup, and it’s also Ford’s only three-cylinder. It’s so small that a Ford spokesman boasted he was able to fit one into his carry-on luggage.

images.caption: Little engine that could: One-liter EcoBoost engine in the Fiesta.
2013 Ford Fiesta is powered by a four-cylinder; next year's model gets the three.
In Europe, the one-liter now powers the seven-seat C-Max.

pageElements.text:
The One-Liter EcoBoost Is Already Big in Europe

The Ford one-liter was named International Engine of the Year this spring, and Ford is already selling it in Europe, where about 30 percent of Focus buyers opt for it. In fact, the whole EcoBoost thing is working out well for Ford, which started making the engines in 2009. The company announced this week that it has passed the 500,000 mark in production of its lineup of fuel-efficient turbocharged engines. By 2013, you'll be able to choose an EcoBoost engine for more than 90 percent of the vehicles Ford sells in North America.

In the Fiesta, the engine is expected to make 123 horsepower and 148 pound-feet of torque, which is actually better than the 2013 Fiesta’s four-cylinder can do. Although fuel economy testing hasn’t happened yet, Bob Fascetti, Ford’s director of global engine engineering, confidently predicted that the Fiesta with the one-liter EcoBoost engine will have the best fuel economy of any non-hybrid on the market.  You can look for numbers well above the current brass ring of 40 mpg.

But How Does It Feel?

Now you may ask, Is this thing going to run like a lawnmower engine, and is it going to sound like one?

A good question when you consider the odd number of cylinders and the diminutive size. In response, Ford enumerated ten ways in which the EcoBoost one-liter has been developed to achieve what Fascetti called “world-class levels of smoothness and refinement.” They range from the wonkish (optimized engine mounts and an offset crankshaft to reduce shaking and friction) to the truly surprising (a sealed rubber belt that reduces noise and requires no maintenance). Fascetti noted that Ford engineers focused on "such things as bearing sizes, piston ring tension, and thermal management," so you don't have to.

No prices are out yet, and the one-liter engine will be an option, not standard equipment, on the 2014 Fiesta.  However, choosing an EcoBoost engine on one of the many other Fords that offer them costs about $995 now. So if you're really set on fuel economy but find diesel or hybrid vehicles out of reach, the 2014 Fiesta with this EcoBoost engine seems like one to put on your short list.

Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

metaTitle: 18 Reasons to Go on a Road Trip with Your Teenager - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: why you should travel with teenagers
metaDescription: There are 18 reasons to go on a road trip with your teenage children, and you will find them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In the summer of 2009, hearing the clock ticking on parenthood and keenly observing the growing independence of my children, I had the crazy idea of a road trip. I talked it over with the family and decided I would drive from Michigan to California and back with my two teenage sons. Max was sixteen, Henry had just turned fourteen, and I wanted them to learn to love travel. Besides, I wanted to go on a major road trip myself.
It was only half our family: the kids' other parent and two younger siblings weren't invited this time. That added to the specialness of going on the trip for my boys, I think.

We drove 6,800 miles in two weeks, passing through South Dakota, turning south and going through Colorado into New Mexico. Next we meandered across northern Arizona and visited both the Grand Canyon and the hippie boarding school in Sedona from which I graduated in 1974, where they had never been. After a 115-degree desert crossing, we bore north to San Francisco, then took the northern route back through Utah and Montana. We had no itinerary, no hotel reservations, and no specific goals. We didn't even have GPS, only a pile of maps and a copy of The Next Stop, an occasionally useful guidebook to what you can find at highway exits nationwide. It wasn't what you'd call an organized trip, but then, my traveling companions weren't what you'd call neat, tidy, or inclined to worry about itinerary changes.

As our minivan pulled back into the driveway just before school started that fall, I felt closer and more connected to my boys than I had since they were babies. I also felt some pride that together, my boys and I powered through boredom, logistical problems, fatigue, fear of heights, and disagreements to have a really, really good time traveling together.
I had no trouble thinking up eighteen reasons why this kind of road trip is a great idea:

images.caption: Max at Mount Rushmore.
The unmissable stop at Wall Drug in South Dakota.
Another Wall Drug tourist attraction.
Henry (left) and Max did a lot of out-of-car running around.
Somewhere east of Laramie.
Most luxurious hotel we stayed in.
On the Four Corners monument, poised over Colorado.
External temperature was 115 degrees.
Irony is everywhere if you travel with teenagers.
On the grounds of Verde Valley School in Arizona, my alma mater.
The guys were in charge of loading and unloading the car.

pageElements.text:
1. Something for you.

You have been putting off traveling to somewhere because you were busy raising kids. Go there, and bring them along.

2. Clock is ticking.

You only have a couple more years of being their day-to-day parent; stick them in the car and go while you still have the authority to do so.

3. Opportunity to talk.

You already know that traveling in the car with your teenagers is the time when you have the best conversations.

4. Training-wheels version of On the Road.

Teenagers are at the most creative time of life, and at the time of life when they are most inclined to take risks. An extended drive with you is a safer, more controlled outlet for adventure on the road than when they will (soon) be doing it alone.

5. Starter course to a life of exploration.

Think of an extended drive as an appetizer that will make them hungry to go explore new places—and you can show them the skills they’ll need to do it.

6. Rediscover your own kids.

You will be showing your kids that you want to spend time with them. You will rediscover that you actually do want to spend time with them.

7. Let them get to know you as a human being.

You will make mistakes and get lost; this will make you a more three-dimensional character to your children. In my case, I had a serious case of fear of heights trying to go through Rocky Mountain National Park. It was stressful, but I felt closer to my boys after it happened, especially after we didn’t go over the edge and crash.

8. Opportunity to learn.

You can back up a book they’re reading or a subject they’re studying with educational (not too educational) side trips or pilgrimages.

9. Opportunity to see family.

Build in an overnight visit or two to far-flung relatives or friends as part of the trip. Bonus: saves hotel $. We spent a night in San Francisco with my friend’s mother, whom my children had never met. My friend was nowhere nearby (she lives in Brooklyn). My friend’s mom was lonely; it was a blast; the boys loved her. She passed away a year later, so that turned out to have been our one chance.

10. Lots of reading together.

Long drives let you listen to books on CD. Be like the commercial where the two guys learn fluent Spanish on a road trip, or do what we did and listen to all of Roots on CD. (Started in Michigan; listened to the final chapter in New Mexico. Then 1984 on the way home.) I know people who read entire books aloud to their family members while on a trip; that would drive me nuts, but YMMV.

11. Learn to trust their judgment.

Let your kids make as many of the travel plans as possible, including route, destination, and a wish list of sights. Example: my middle son’s main request was to see Mt. Rushmore. That was our first stop, and we planned our drive west around it.

12. See schools and scout locations.

If your children are ready to consider where to go to college, use this as a chance to make informal trips to colleges and especially to college towns. We swung through the hip pedestrian malls of Iowa City and gave the guys a whole new way of looking at what they had thought of as an agrarian state. But keep a road trip separate from a college trip or you will taint the experience.

13. Eat foods you wouldn’t normally.

Go to regional restaurants rather than chains; stop at roadside stands; and my favorite, scout out a diner in small town stops, the one where they look at you strangely because they don’t know you and it’s unexpected to see non-locals walk in. Plus, what the heck, let them eat sunflower seeds and Pringles in the car and drink Big Gulps. They’re teenagers.

14. Shop with a teenager’s eye for irony.

Collect something cheap that will be fun to have later, such as guitar-case stickers or postcards (we hit the jackpot at a fuel stop in desert California where there were retro car stickers from every state). Bring home rattlesnake jerky or Moon Pies.

15. Get off the Interstate.

When you can, take the Blue Highways and see what the region is really like. The remoteness and tedium of driving across New Mexico and Arizona’s reservation lands was perhaps the most memorable stretch of our drive because it was utterly unlike anything at home.

16. Force sibling interaction.

If you've got more than one teenager on the trip, there's the bonus (sometimes the problem) of their own travel relationship. Siblings who played together for hours a day in elementary school may drift apart as teens. They will forge a new chapter in their relationship if they spend two weeks in the car together. Hint: Drive a minivan or SUV that gives each of them some personal space; be a uniter, not a torturer.

17. Rack up driving hours.

If your kids have their permits and need highway experience, if they’re cocky new drivers and need lots of hours with you as a back-seat driver, or if they are already excellent drivers and can give you long breaks from driving during a trip, those are all good things.

18. Life is short, people.

It is really so short. Press Pause on your life and those of your kids and go somewhere together.
Just as your parenting experience isn't really over at age eighteen, this list isn't quite over yet, either. Here are...

Three cardinal rules to keep your expectations grounded.


19. Don’t expect complete harmony.

They’ll be bored and crabby sometimes; you’ll be impatient and crabby sometimes. Accept it now, and hold the fake cheerfulness to a strict minimum.

20. Don’t make everything into a learning experience.

They won’t care about the historical significance of some location you’ve been looking forward to, or they will want to leave a place you thought they were going to adore. Get over it.

21. Don’t try to make this the One Life-Changing Trip.

If life is a banquet, taking your kids on a driving trip should be more like grazing than stuffing yourselves. See what you see, and get as far as you get, and enjoy that.

pageElements.text: The 2013 Cadillac XTS takes customization to a new level with a choice of four digital instrument clusters. The all-new car offers the choice on its Premium and Platinum models, the top two of four trim levels on the XTS. The 2013 Cadillac XTS Premium starts at $55,425, and the XTS Platinum is priced starting at $60,000, including destination.

Powered by Cadillac's Cue telematics system, the choice of layouts is controlled by a multidirectional switch on the car's steering wheel. Instead of an old-style analog gauge cluster, the XTS has a 12.3-inch LCD screen that you set up the way you want. Here are the four choices:
    The balanced display setting is the default. Looking like what you'd expect to see on a Cadillac's dash, this display has three zones to show speedometer and tachometer, fuel level, audio system information, and outside temperature numbers.
    The performance layout gives equal space to tachometer and speedometer, consistent with a driver focused on a more invigorating experience. Fuel consumption, tire pressure, and other specs can be added at will.
    The enhanced display choice is intended to look more like surfing the Internet than staring at a dashboard. There's a navigation map at the left, with fuel and speed information at right. You scroll through pages of information, computer style.
    Is that more excitement than you care to have from your dash display? The simple layout may be more your speed. This one has fuel level, speedometer, and radio displays, and that's it.

Or maybe you really want to play hardball with the whole digital-display thing. In that case, you'll enjoy that the XTS has a screen-within-a-screen feature that lets you control audio and navigation features from a smaller screen inside the speedometer and tachometer images.
How do you control and change the screens? Using the screen, of course.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: With the holiday season upon us and family togetherness at its yearly peak, it’s a good time to check in with older family members and consider how they are managing driving.  At least, that is what the American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA) is hoping we will do during Older Driver Safety Awareness Week (December 3-7).

Throughout the week, AOTA, AAA, AARP, and The Hartford Financial Services Group will be highlighting different aspects of older driver safety and providing tips and resources to prolong safe driving well past retirement.

Ten thousand people turn sixty-five every day. That number will increase as people born during the peak years of the baby boom earn their senior discount cards. This aging baby boom means that maintaining the safety of older drivers is becoming more important than ever, especially since many older people find themselves without access to alternative forms of transportation.

Luckily, boomers are aging into better medical care that will keep them healthier longer, and better in-car technology that may help deal with some of the challenges of aging – for example, better headlights, crash mitigation, and lane departure systems. Older Driver Safety Awareness Week aims to bring attention to those technologies and provide resources to help drivers and their families decide if staying behind the wheel is still the right choice.

We’ll be bringing you thoughts and information on safety and older drivers this week, and you can head over to AOTA’s website to check out more resources and discussions. If you’re looking for a more interactive approach to Older Driver Safety Awareness Week, AARP will be hosting a live Twitter chat Wednesday at 3 p.m. (EST) to discuss older drivers and the difficult question of when it’s time to put away the keys for good.

pageElements.text: Here we are at the heart of the holiday season, and the peak of retailing, and you are probably still shopping for a few things. What if I told you I have five ideas to make you a hero to some little kid? Maybe your own little kid, in fact?

#1: Remote-Control Ferrari Enzo

Let's start with a 1/16-scale Ferrari Enzo. Sure, it’s good-looking. Sure, it’s a remote-control Ferrari. But wait, there’s more. It is remote controlled via iPhone, so it solves the biggest drawback of a remote-controlled toy: those chintzy controllers. I have hated those things all my children's lives. The antenna breaks! You can’t get the weird little batteries out! If you get them out, you can’t locate the right kind to replace them!

Not so with this toy. This one works through an app for iPhone, iPad, or iPod Touch, and it also takes four garden-variety AA batteries. You can use it inside or out, up to thirty feet away, and you can control steering, accelerating, and braking. Plus, as you go faster, audio sampling puts out actual audio from a real Ferrari’s engine. Turn signals, hazard lights, headlights, and horn all work. But be honest: who is going to use a turn signal with this Enzo?
Hammacher Schlemmer $99.95

#2: Lego VW Van

Are you looking for something for the Legomaniac in your family? The classic 1962 Volkswagen T1 Camper Van rides again in a 1,334-piece Lego set, available from various chain stores or direct from Lego.com. The split safari windshield and pop-up roof will make you remember (or wish you remembered) the Summer of Love. The Lego-brick interior is no-frills basic, but then, so was the interior of the real thing.
Lego.com $119.99

#3: BMWs for All Ages

BMW’s understated yet confident sporting style is available to the youngest members of the family. The preschool-age Junior Bike is a black-and-red tricycle with “noise-canceling rubber wheels” and “optimized ergonomics.” BMW also has a two-wheeler, available in three colors, and a Baby Racer for the toddler at $108. The hot ticket is the Baby Racer II M3 edition, with a rear spoiler, a horn (you may regret that), an M steering wheel, and a full set of gauges, including a tachometer. Considering that the eighteen-month-old recipient of this M3 won’t be able to pronounce “tachometer,” that’s pretty funny, but there’s no doubt this will steal the show under the tree on Christmas morning.
Shop BMW USA Baby Racer $108-$121, Junior Bike $123, Kid’s Bike $353

#4: Quattro for the Under-Quattro Age Group

pageElements.text: Perhaps one of the most poetic moments of my life was when I walked out of my last session of driver’s ed, test passed and mere weeks away from four-wheeled freedom, to see that my bike had been stolen. I have ridden a bike exactly once since (this was a closely-guarded secret during my time working at a bicycle advocacy nonprofit) and I’ve never missed it. My heart belongs to things that go vroom.

Great Day, Lousy Photo

On my sixteenth birthday, I skipped school and had my dad drive me to the nearest Secretary of State branch office as soon as it opened. I stood in line, took one of the worst pictures I’ve ever taken (people – strangers, even – used to break into laughter as soon as they saw it), drove my dad home, and then drove back to school, alone on the road for the first time.

How Life Should Always Feel

They say you always remember your first drive, and I still remember mine. I was listening to “Do You Believe in Magic” of 1960s fame. I had the exhilarating feeling I still get when I’m driving too fast or at the beginning of a long trip. It’s also the feeling I get when I’m skiing down a mountain and I realize it’s fifty-fifty that I make it down in one piece. It’s how life should always feel. It was great.
Later that day, I ran the second-fastest 5K of my life. Then my parents tried to give me a curfew, and I refused it. And the rest is history!

pageElements.text: There will be a day in every car owner’s life when the dreaded fender bender or accident with a wild animal will occur. Not only are you shaken up from the impact, but now you have to worry about insurance and where you’ll take your car for collision repairs.

If you have a trusted mechanic or dealership, deciding where to take your car for repairs may not be a problem. But for those who are looking for a body shop they can trust, going with one that is part of a franchise network is worth considering rather than taking your chances with a local mom-and-pop operation.
Carstar is one such franchise network composed of more than 400 independently owned and operated stores in thirty-one states and ten Canadian provinces.

Carstar CEO David Byers says his company takes on existing independent repair shops, consolidating them under the Carstar franchise umbrella. That's what is known as "conversion franchising." Conversion franchising allows independent shop owners to remain so, but also provides them with the support of a centralized management team; training in collision repair, financial management, and customer service; and the ability to work with a larger number of insurance companies via Carstar’s insurance staff liaisons.
The advantage for you, the customer, is that you are still dealing with an independently run business, but one with the advantages of a larger organizational structure:

1. A franchised shop is part of a brand. This probably seems like a real no-brainer, but think about it for a few minutes. A trustworthy mechanic can be as rare as independent garages are plentiful. If you’re looking for an independent repair shop and think you have reason to be suspicious, you have a whole host of ways to check that the facility you choose provides high-quality service. But with a franchised shop, you don’t have to go through all of that work. Byers says that if you choose a known brand to service your car, there are more ways to be assured of the quality of work you’ll be receiving.

By calling a toll-free number or chatting online with a service representative, Carstar provides accident assistance twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. In the event of an accident, Carstar can call your insurance company and have your vehicle towed to begin the repair process and will even call a family member or friend at your request. The company employs certified technicians who receive ongoing training in customer service practices, working with new vehicle materials and technologies like carbon fiber and waterborne paint, and using new repair processes. Carstar also performs a fifty-point interior and exterior quality inspection and a test drive before returning your car to you and offers detailing work to return the car to like-new condition.

2. Carstar works with all vehicle makes and models and all insurance companies. If your car is new or still under warranty, it makes the most sense to take it to the dealership to be repaired by company-trained mechanics. However, for someone like me who drives a thirteen-year-old car, going to the dealership where my great-uncle purchased the car makes neither financial nor logistical sense (both my great-uncle and the dealership are about three hours away from my home). According to Byers, neither the age of the vehicle nor the make or model will affect Carstar technicians' abilities to perform auto body repairs. Carstar technicians are trained to work on all cars, regardless of their age or nation of origin. To make the repair process smoother for the customer, Carstar also retains a team of insurance experts who coordinate vehicle repair with more than eighty insurance carriers, including well-known ones such as Allstate, Farmers Insurance Group, Geico, Liberty Mutual, Nationwide, and Progressive.

3. Your car is always safe and never really out of your sight. A universal worry when a car enters a shop for collision repair is whether it’s safe and whether it's actually being worked on. In most situations, you have no way to assure yourself that the car is being repaired. Something that you won’t find at the usual collision repair facility is what Byers's company calls Carstar Vision. This lets you get a look at your car online from the beginning to the end of the repair process. You log in and can view photos of the progress of your vehicle repair. You can also send questions or comments to the mechanic and receive answers. Carstar also sends e-mail updates concerning the car’s repair status.

4. Your repair comes with a warranty. Once your car has been fixed, something could go wrong, and back to the shop you’ll go. Carstar offers a nationwide five-year warranty that covers labor and materials. You can return the car to the same location or any other Carstar store to make things right. The warranty is guaranteed as long as the repaired car remains in your possession but is not transferable if ownership of the vehicle changes hands.

5. Financing is available. Carstar also allows you to pay off repair charges in monthly installments with financing through its CarCareONE credit card. The interest rate, currently over 28 percent, is undesirable, but if you were going to use a high-interest credit card anyway, it's an option to consider.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. pageElements.text: I need a time machine, quick. I just got a peek at the future, and I need to get there right away.

Remember when James Bond used his smartphone as a remote control for his BMW 750iL in Tomorrow Never Dies? That technology is so sixteen years ago. I just watched a demonstration at the 2013 International Consumer Electronics Show (CES) where a “busy executive” (played by an Audi representative) pulled up in front of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Las Vegas and leaped out of his car. “He’s late for his meeting,” I was told. Even so, he did not hand the keys to the sweet Audi prototype he was driving to a valet. Instead, he whipped out his smartphone and tapped it as he walked briskly and callously away from his now driverless car and into the hotel.

Dutifully, the unmanned Audi drove out of the hotel entryway and around the corner to the parking garage, where it negotiated the entry turnstile, located an empty parking space, and backed into it skillfully. It even executed a fussily precise parking correction before it was satisfied enough to turn off its own headlights and shut off its engine. I assume it was tempted to chat on the phone and listen to its radio while it waited. But it didn’t. It just waited.

images.caption: "Piloted driving," they call it. Nobody at the wheel but  sensors.
Putting the Audi into Jeeves mode is simple.
Here's the indicator that the car is not in your hands anymore.
Notification by smartphone, so James Bond.
How long till we can summon our cars out of the garage this way?
Audi demonstrated the Connect technology at the Consumer Electronics Show.

pageElements.text: The exec’s meeting was apparently short, because in a few minutes, he was back, tapping his phone again as he exited the hotel. The parked car fired up its engine, pulled out of the parking space, and drove back to the hotel’s front door to pick him up. If this had not been a demo, the two would presumably have driven off together into the sunset.

The phone Bond used was a fake, mocked up by Ericsson for that movie. And it certainly wasn’t controlling that BMW. But the phone and car in the demo at CES are for real. The phone was just a smartphone. The car is a state-of-the-art demonstration of how far Audi has come in the quest for a car that can drive itself.

It's All in the Sensors

Sensing disbelief among members of the audience, the Audi folks invited us to look inside the vehicle to confirm that there wasn’t a very short driver stashed in the back seat. (I looked. There wasn’t.) The only smoke and mirrors here were the sensors the Audi folks had installed in the parking garage – something that will likely be built into parking garages in the future. Audi had also cleared the area of pedestrians carefully, because the car and sensors are, after all, prototypes. The car is equipped with an array of sensors that allow it to “see” the world in order to pilot itself. It can recognize street signs, objects, people, parking spaces, and other cars. The garage sensors are a safety redundancy.

So now I am desperately Googling time machines. I want in on this car-as-chauffeur business. Sure, I’m afraid of an apocalypse brought on by angry, sentient machines just like any other geek. But I hate looking for parking.

Technology Is There; A Date to Launch, Not Quite Yet

I’ve been hearing from many carmakers that the technology for self-piloted cars exists. Toyota was showing its fully autonomous Lexus LS-based car on the show floor, too. However, that car was parked on a pedestal. And I suppose part of me just wasn’t quite buying it. But now I’ve seen it with my own eyes. This same car could also take over driving in hateful slow-moving freeway situations or take the wheel for a bit so I can grab a snack or send a text. (Audi also demonstrated a virtual simulation of this scenario in its booth on the show floor at CES, using video of the traffic and a controller rigged out of an Audi driver’s seat.)

This demonstration was meant to prove that the technology is pretty much ready, but there are all sorts of non-technical obstacles standing between me and ownership of a vehicle like this one. Legislation is just one. Who is liable if the car gets into an accident when no one is at the wheel? There are others. Humans may not be ready to trust technology this much, parking structures lack the infrastructure, and so on. But parts of this technology will certainly be working their way into new cars slowly. In fact, if your car has lane correction or adaptive cruise control, it is well on its way to becoming a sentient being.

Audi won’t predict when a car this capable might go into production. But unless I find that time machine, it’s likely I will have to wait as much as ten years to fetch my car from blocks away with a tap on my smartphone. I’m just not sure I can wait that long.

pageElements.text: When you drive your car in to a repair facility, whether an independent shop or a dealership's service department, do you know how to speak the language? If you aren't clear in describing your problem, you might not be able to get the repair people on the same page with you. As a result, you might be missing out on the thorough and accurate service job you expect.

So, first, get out a note pad, enlist a friend or family member to help you, and answer these questions as fully as you can.
1. What, exactly, does the noise or problem sound like?
2. Is the problem happening when the engine is cold or when it has warmed up?
3. Does it tend to happen more under certain conditions, such as at a certain speed or when you hit a bump?
4. Does the noise tend to speed up or slow down, based on how fast you’re driving?
5. Can you figure out where the sound or problem is coming from?

pageElements.text: Ford announced a new project at January’s Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, but it’s not a car – it’s potentially even more important than that. The auto company is teaming up with Eaton, SunPower, and Whirlpool on this project. Down the road, it will lead to a household full of connected products: everything from appliances to the plug-in electric vehicle in your future garage.
MyEnergi Lifestyle is Ford’s way of helping us cut our carbon footprint and spend less on energy at home. Who doesn’t want to do that?

The collaboration won’t result in a physical product from Ford. Instead, it grants the other collaborators access to an existing Ford database so that they can build those connected products. The database keeps track of time-of-day utility charges across the country to help owners of Ford’s electrified vehicles avoid charging their cars during peak hours, when rates for electricity are higher.

How Does It Work?

By waiting until off-peak hours, which typically occur at night when the demand on the grid is lower, Ford says MyEnergi Lifestyle can help homeowners save up to 60 percent on their household energy bills, citing a study from the Georgia Institute of Technology.

The same study says that replacing old household appliances with energy-efficient ones and switching from a car that earns 25 mpg on the highway to a plug-in vehicle can result in up to a 55 percent reduction in a household’s carbon footprint.

Some of the products that have access to Ford’s database are already on sale: the C-Max Energi and the accompanying MyFord Mobile app, for instance.  The others will be available by the end of the first quarter of 2013.

Household Appliances Going Smart and Green

Whirlpool’s 6th Sense Live line of products will be on sale in the Chicago area starting in March, and includes a washer, dryer, dishwasher, refrigerator, and accompanying smartphone app. SunPower will offer a solar charger with accompanying app that can allow households to switch to solar power during peak hours to save money. Eaton will offer a variety of power management appliances, including a home charging station (costing either $1,075 for 16-amp charger or $1,175 for a 30-amp one) and solar power inverter. Another collaborator, Nest Labs, sells a $249 self-programming thermostat that saves money and energy by learning your routine and automatically adjusting your home temperature.

Since each company has its own accompanying app, buyers can acquire any combination of appliances and take advantage of MyEnergi Lifestyle without having to shell out for a dozen new appliances and a car all at once.  The apps also operate without requiring input from the consumer. Once the refrigerator is hooked up to the related app, it will automatically wait until nighttime to perform high-energy functions. No need to remind it every day.

pageElements.text:
Synergy of Household and Garage

It may seem strange to think about an automaker teaming up with home appliance manufacturers, but Ford’s global director of vehicle electrification and infrastructure, Mike Tinskey, says it's an idea whose time has come. "The time is right for the home appliance and transportation sectors to converge," he says, to tackle the many "sustainability challenges” ahead.

Those words may be tough to hear for us “love of the drive” types, but for the growing ranks of young people and city dwellers who see car ownership as a costly burden, this could strike just the right chord.

pageElements.text: Jacqueline lives in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where she is a pediatric nurse who holds a bachelor of science in nursing from the University of Michigan. She has a black Labrador retriever named Cleo. She runs 5Ks and 10Ks and enjoys volunteer work. Her car is a 2008 Toyota RAV4. Her dream car does not depart from that practical profile: she'd choose a Land Rover LR2. Her thoughts on auto issues:

Distracted Driving/Texting while Driving: “It’s a big concern. It not only puts you in danger, it puts innocents in danger. It has a lot to do with cell-phone usage and with people not focusing on what they are doing. I put my cell phone on speaker, and I have Bluetooth in the car. I’ve been distracted in the past, and I’ve run into curbs and had to get new tires. It happened twice in the first year I had my car.”

Auto Styling: “I’m liking what I see. I just like all of the new technological innovations. The backup camera in the rearview mirror, a car that parallel parks itself. I like less boxy cars and lines that are less angular. But I do like the Land Rover. Cars that look like a cube don’t please me. The new Honda Civic is a favorite of mine. I don’t like the new Honda CR-V, though. I test drove it, and it didn’t ride smoothly. I would never buy a pickup truck. It seems a little too masculine to me.”

Gas Prices: “I am concerned that there are people with good college degrees who aren’t making enough to support driving in areas that don’t have mass transit. I worry that people won’t be able to afford to drive. My RAV4 costs between $45 and $50 to fill. Right now, because of my finances, I have to not spend on other areas because of gas.”

Technology/Autonomous Driving: “I’m a control freak. I like that there is new tech, but I also want the option of still controlling the car on my own. I think that there are pluses and minuses for technology – especially as someone coming from the health care world. There will be new innovations, but you can’t lose sight of how things started. Something has to be said for tradition. You can’t lose sight of the good old days.”

Electric/Alt-Fuel Vehicles: “I would buy one as long as I had the amenities, such as the ability to plug it in. An electric vehicle is an investment in your future. If it’s more energy efficient, you get more bang for your buck in the long run, even if in the short run it’s a little more expensive.”

pageElements.text: Recently we saw this photo of car designers at an automotive design conference, seven men and one woman, all looking casual and most wearing jeans. We wondered who the young woman was amid all the testosterone. A few calls got us to Elena Ristancevska at the Volkswagen Group's Skoda Auto Design Center outside Prague.

Twenty-nine-year-old, Macedonia-born Ristancevska has had a career in auto design that has been rather charmed and meteoric. With no design background in her family, she went from college in Skopje, Macedonia, to an elite design school outside Milan in Como, Italy. From there, she won an internship at the nearby Mercedes-Benz Advanced Design Studio. Located in the Villa Salazar, where the late Italian fashion lion Gianni Versace had a studio, the elegant quarters housed small teams focused on the interiors of cars that would steer Mercedes-Benz into the future. It was an internship that other car-design wannabes would have died for.
It all sounded exotic and exciting to us, so we chased the busy Elena Ristancevska down for photos and peppered her with questions.

First, how did you get from the mountains of Macedonia to design school in Italy with famous designers and a view of the Alps?

Studying in Skopje I saw a sign on a bulletin board: Italian Universities Seeking Foreign Students. I went for tests. There were all these Italians around, and I didn't speak the language that well. The design department of the technical university [where Ristancevska was accepted] was in Como, near the lake. I spent three wonderful years there. My mentor mentioned a nearby auto design studio: "Maybe you should try there. You have this sense for mixing colors and design together."

And at twenty-six, you joined the Mercedes-Benz Advanced Design Studio in Como?

I was really lucky. Valeria Vigevani was the color and trim designer, with me as intern. I was part of the creative process on proposals. I did the proposal for the steering wheel on the Mercedes-Benz Concept Style Coupe. It was presented at Auto China in Beijing in 2012. For the new E-Class 2014 Mercedes, I worked on color and materials with other designers for the general interior.

After six months there, you decided to stay in car design?

When I started my studies, I was not well informed. Transportation design was not as famous as today. Now it is a dream to get into car design. After Mercedes I got job offers. I decided to work freelance until I could decide which company offered me the best future. Quite a few designers in Europe do freelance. They want to work in the auto industry but, at the same time, be free. Not have certain work times or rules. They can have a different private life.

Why did you join Skoda and the VW Group?

It was an opportunity to develop my knowledge. VW is considered the best group, you know: Skoda, Volkswagen, Bentley, Porsche, Audi, Lamborghini [and six more].

Skoda has been on fire in China lately, selling 25 percent of its cars there. Are you interested in working in China, where Skoda has a design studio in Shanghai?

Everything is going very fast there. It is a complicated market. [During the interview, a design colleague of Ristancevska's commented that China is a market where color, chrome, and size are most attractive, and where design is preferred over practicality.] I would like to see how things work in the United States because the markets are all different: EU, U.S., China.

So we might see you designing cars in the United States?

Yeah...why not? I would like to try. Every move outside these borders is a new experience. I admire cultures. Maybe it will be...one day. I hope.

What's a day like in the Skoda design studio?

We are encouraged to be free thinking. Some days I may spend ten to twelve hours, depending on the project, and come home completely tired. I don't have time then for chatting with friends or caring for my flat. On weekends, I am like a desperate housewife sometimes. [Note: She's single.] Other times I go out. I have fun.

Do you like futuristic-looking electric cars?

We wish to see futuristic cars on the streets, no matter if they are electric or classic ones. The outstanding electric car, and it's in production, is the Tesla Model S.

You came to cars after focusing on consumer products, like furniture and perfume bottles. Do you notice design in everything?

I'm getting inspiration from furniture, buildings. I must say, it is all connected. You must follow the social trends to create. Architecture, architecture of the future, fashion. I am reading a lot of blogs, books.

Let's say you had enough of car design. What would you do next?

Product design. I would not change from design for a different field for anything.

What makes a car appeal to a young, fashion-conscious woman?

The eye catcher is mostly the exterior. Right now, red is an attractive color for women, but the color impact depends on size and shape. What looks good on an SUV may not on a sports car.

Is anything especially fashionable?

[She smiles.] To include handbag hooks on the dash. It is easier to get lipstick.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.
Go back to the series introduction and catch up with the full story! Okay, are you back and loving the Notorious Women as much as I am?

Bebe Daniels

Hollywood was quite a car-crazy place back in the 1910s and 1920s. Imagine the heady excitement of the turn of the century fueled by a movie industry in its infancy, the suffragist movement heating up, and this exciting new form of transportation catapulting the country toward the future. Imagine the girls gone wild.

One of these wild girls, and the first woman convicted of speeding in Orange County, was nineteen-year-old silent screen siren Bebe Daniels, who began her film career at the age of seven, having acted on stage since the age of four. So we’re looking at a pretty seasoned trouper here, a girlfriend of Jack Dempsey and, by all accounts, Miss Popularity among her fellow stars.

How Fast Could That Marmon Roadster Go?

Miss Daniels was an inveterate speeder. "One of the things I enjoyed most, when I wasn’t making films, was speeding," she wrote. Bebe had a Marmon roadster in 1921, a huge and powerful car more suited to the Brickyard than Highway 101. And she was used to getting tickets. She’d call up her Uncle Jack, who she said was an important Los Angeles newspaperman who had an in with the cops. He’d smooth things over and pay her fines.

Only this time, when she was pulled over for going 56.25 mph on her way to San Juan Capistrano, where the judge was famous for putting anyone who drove more than 50 mph straight into jail, the long arm of Uncle Jack’s influence didn’t reach. "Where are you?" he asked her when the inevitable call for an assist came. "Orange County," she answered. "Baby," he replied, "you’re in the wrong county."
Bebe’s lawyer asked for a change of venue for the case. The judge denied the motion, but Bebe was famous enough to have the court date postponed a couple of months so she could finish a movie.

"I Do Not Relish Jail"

More than 1,500 spectators showed up outside the courthouse on the day of the trial. "Will Bebe Vamp Justice Cox?" the Los Angeles Times headlined the story. "Judge Cox need have no fear that I will try to vamp him," she was quoted. "I don’t want to make him angry, for if I do, I will probably go to jail. I do not relish jail."

When her flimsy excuse was thrown out and she was sentenced to ten days in the local slammer, she said of the judge, "I suppose if you live in a small town you get like that. I bet 56.25 mph sounds awfully fast if you’ve never driven anything faster than a plow."

image.caption: Bebe Daniels maintained a guestbook inside the jail.

pageElements.text:
The Speed Girl

Judge Cox apparently didn’t take it personally. He brought her a dozen roses and signed her prison guestbook. According to the guestbook, she received a total of 792 visitors during her prison stay. Fatty Arbuckle even sent her a note reading: "Houdini’s in town. Can we help?"

Abe Lyman and his orchestra played outside her window every night, and a local restaurant delivered three meals a day. A furniture store brought in an ivory bedroom set and a rocking chair, and a fan sent her a Victrola with 150 records.
The minute she got out, she began filming The Speed Girl on location at the scene of her trial. It hit the theaters that fall.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The sweet six-year-old girl that you see in this photo is now sixteen and is counting down the days until she can drive without any supervision. You know, life really begins when you can pull out of the driveway without a parent. At least, it did for me, but that's another story. She is the perfect daughter in almost every way, but her attention span is shorter than that of Chuy from Chelsea Lately. The nightly ritual of homework is filled with constant nagging to focus. One by one, I have to remind her: turn off your phone, no YouTube, no Facebook, turn down the music. Once she is in a car alone, who is going to keep her focused? The consequences are much higher than when she does a sloppy job on a homework assignment.

Michigan has a graduated license process for anyone under eighteen. My daughter has completed the first segment, which included twenty four hours of class time, six hours of driving with the school's instructors, and a state-required written exam. I was horrified when she barely passed the test and the driving school didn't even go over the questions that she had missed. I was the obnoxious mom who asked the instructor to stay and help her review her mistakes. Seriously, this shit matters.

On a Scale of One to Ten

The next day, we were off to the Secretary of State to get her passport to freedom. During this phase, she will have a permit but is required to spend fifty hours of supervised driving with an adult driver who is over twenty-one. I asked her: On a scale of one to ten, with ten being an expert driver, where does she think she stands. "Prolly an eight," she responded.

I like the confidence, but if Jeff Gordon is a ten, I'm thinking I'm a six and she is a one. But I have to remember that when she goes to the doctor for anything, she always gives her pain level as a ten.

The Scariest Hour

My husband decided to have her drive that very night to Bloomfield Hills, a fifty-minute drive with tricky highway exchanges and four miles on uber-busy Orchard Lake Road at night. Quick reminder: she had driven a total of six hours. She confidently slipped into the driver's seat and began what I consider to be the scariest hour of my life. She is actually a very smooth driver but is quite timid. She also drives way far to the right in her lane, and takes very wide sweeping turns. My husband sat in the front and guided her in a very laid-back manner, while every now and then I would interject in a shrill, terrified voice. I finally closed my eyes and pretended I was on a ride at Disneyland.

Gathering of the Helicopter Parents

Several days later, I found an e-mail in my in box asking me to take part in a focus group for parents of students who have just begun this supervised driving time with their teens. My helicopter had landed! I responded immediately: Yes, please.

I surmised that the participants would likely be other helis who were taking the job of supervisor just as seriously as I was. When I arrived, I learned that we were taking part in a study to create a parent coaching guide. The focus group was conducted by the Young Driver Behavior and Injury Prevention at the University of Michigan's Transportation Research Institute.
They had me at Injury Prevention.

As they rolled out the various sections that they would be including in the guide, I realized that we had gone from zero to sixty with our daughter waaaay too fast. Their first step involves practicing in an empty parking lot and checking off skills in an organized manner, not hopping in the car and immediately heading for the nearest heavily congested highway. Brilliant.

The facilitators explained that this supervised driving period offers a unique opportunity to reduce teen drivers' risk of being in a crash. Other parent guides exist, but few focus on the actual practice of critical driving skills, and none are evidence based. This parent coaching guide is intended to help parents use effective communication, coaching techniques, and practice exercises with their teen, which will let us coach them in acquiring skills that are critical to safety.
Now these people were talking my language.

Group Therapy for Parents of Teen Drivers

As we worked our way through the steps, the group shared their experiences as supervisors. One woman's daughter has had her license for eight months, but they have only been out twice because they are both terrified. One man shared how he can't do it, either, so his friends and relatives help out. It was a bit of a group therapy session where we commiserated about how ill-equipped we all feel.

When I shared the story of my daughter's drive to Bloomfield the night she got her permit, the group went silent. Their reactions reminded me of the look on my daughter's face late one night at a family gathering when all of her cousins went to put on their jammies and I had forgotten to bring hers. Bad mom!

Jean Knows Driving

The University of Michigan study results will not be available in time to help us, but I did take away the idea to build my daughter's skills slowly. It is not going to make her happy, but we are going to go back to the empty parking lot and make sure she has nailed the basics.

I have asked Jean to step in and give her a crash (not literally) course in the finer points of driving. Jean promised to squeeze her in this spring. Stand by to read all about the Jean master classes! I am sure that my daughter will appreciate getting lessons from madcap Jean, rather than starring in the reality show So You Think You Can Drive? with me playing the part of the super-crabby judge.

2013 Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG

Vital Stats

Base price: $135,205 (includes destination)
This car's price: $137,505 (includes destination and $2,300 designo Mystic Brown exterior paint color)
EPA fuel economy: 12 mpg city/14 mpg highway (with 4Matic permanent all-wheel drive, 5.5-liter biturbo V-8, seven-speed automatic transmission)
Safety features: Parktronic electronic parking aid, Distronic Plus adaptive cruise control, blind spot assist, electronic stability control (ESP), brake assist, adaptive brake technology
Tech features: Bluetooth connectivity with audio streaming, Comand system with navigation, iPod/MP3 interface, Harman Kardon Logic7 surround sound, Mbrace2 telematics
Chief competitors: Cadillac Escalade Hybrid, BMW X6M

Key Points

Do you love it or hate it? The Gelandewagen is a cult classic but has also been lampooned as "the most awesomely ridiculous vehicle you can buy today."
Well, it did start out as a military machine. Today, though, it's hand built and goes to seekers of high-end luxury and distinctiveness.
There's an incredible list of luxury features on board: a heated windshield, Harman Kardon surround sound, and mbrace2, designed to bring the Internet to the dashboard with features like around-the-clock concierge services and a "real-life co-pilot" who provides turn-by-turn directions. Take that, Siri!
Let's not forget the luxury Neck-Pro head restraints, which are connected to an electronic control unit that can sense a rear-end collision about to happen and move the head restraints up and forward in the milliseconds before impact.
Safety features bring the G63 about as close to autonomous driving as we see in a 2013 production vehicle.
544-horsepower twin-turbo engine is useful in getting this 5,800-pound vehicle from 0 to 60 mph in 5.2 seconds.
The only EPA-rated car with worse fuel economy is the Bugatti Veyron.
The only vehicle you can buy that is this crazily distinctive is...can't think of a thing.

Leaving the actresses behind momentarily, we return to an adventurer. Aloha Wanderwell, like our intrepid pioneers Bertha Benz, Alice Ramsey, and Anita King, was known for breaking a barrier: she was the first woman on record to have driven around the world. Unlike them, she was not necessarily a good girl. Aloha Wanderwell was rumored to have played a role in the murder of her husband.

Born Idris Hall in Canada, and later as a student in a French convent school, she dreamed of traveling the world. At the age of sixteen, she got her chance when she was hired as secretary and driver on an around-the-world film expedition. The leader was Walter Wanderwell, a Polish seafarer and traveler who styled himself as Captain even though he held no real military rank. Driving custom-fitted Ford Model Ts, the expedition traveled through forty-three countries between 1922 and 1925, including Morocco, China, Romania, Egypt, and Siberia.

Why the Model T?

Aloha wrote of the expedition's Model Ts that the Ford was "the only vehicle" for a trip in the 1920s. "Light weight: can be raised by its occupants. Good clearance: imperative. Repairs: simple. Basic: the only global spare parts service makes it the most influential auto. The Flivver will open the roads of the world." She seems to have not just endured, but enjoyed the ride. In her writing, she mused that "the confines of a car, its reassuring purr and motion, breeds an extraordinary sense of isolation, intimacy, privacy."

Aloha served as interpreter, seamstress, laundress, mechanic, cinematographer, and film editor on the expedition. In 1925, she also became Wanderwell's second wife. Their collaboration included intrepid episodes such as the time their plane crashed in the Amazon basin, and Aloha had to be left behind for months while Walter made his way back to civilization to get parts to repair the plane. She used the time to make a movie, Flight to the Stone Age Bororos, which is now in the Smithsonian's Human Studies Archive.

They came out of their around-the-world voyage with a film, With Car and Camera around the World, prominently featuring Aloha, and hit the lecture circuit. Some of the nitrate film footage survives, and it's a fascinating look at a more adventurous time in travel.

Murder Mystery

In 1932, Aloha and Walter were in Long Beach, California, preparing for a trip to the South Seas to make another film. On the night of December 5, Walter was shot and killed in the cabin of their boat. Although Aloha was reportedly in Hollywood closing the deal on the documentary at the time, there were persistent rumors that she had a hand in her husband's death.
A crew member from one of Walter's previous voyages, William "Curly" Guy, was tried for the murder but acquitted, and the crime remains unpunished to this day.

Meanwhile, Aloha remarried to another filmmaker, Walter Baker, and together they completed a list of films including Flight to the Stone Age, My Hawaii, To See the World by Car, and Explorers of the Purple Sage. Some are in the permanent collections of the Library of Congress, the Smithsonian, and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

But what happened to the Ford Model T? Aloha donated it to Ford, but unfortunately, Henry Ford himself decided its historical value was limited, and he had it handed over to be used as scrap metal for the war effort  in 1942. Too bad, because it would have been a great addition to the car collection at the Henry Ford Museum.

pageElements.text: If you're one of the unfortunate souls who spend your life cursing pollen in all its forms, or if you spent your childhood avoiding the cheap but adorable nickel earrings sold at mall kiosks, Ford has good news for you. Finally, there is a car designed specifically with the allergy afflicted in mind.

The engineers behind the 2013 Ford Fusion have gone to great lengths to ensure that allergy sufferers will be comfortable behind the wheel. For starters, the team of engineers tested more than 100 materials for allergy problems. They avoided using materials like latex, hexavalent chromium (found in dyes, paints, and plastics), and nickel for the car's most touched surfaces (like the steering wheel and center console), since those materials are prone to cause allergic reactions. Ford also chose to limit the use of dyes and formaldehyde in the car's fabrics to further limit the chances that the car will contain allergens.

Ford is also seeking to reduce in-car allergen levels by testing and installing cabin air filters. These air filters catch dust, spores, pollen, and fungus, as well as soot, smog, and smoke, and prevent them from entering the car.

Sync's Allergy Alert App

Ford vehicles equipped with Sync have already been helping allergy sufferers with the Allergy Alert app, which can give drivers location-specific allergy information and inform them of asthma and flu risks without their eyes leaving the road. This new focus on allergens is just one part of Ford's larger plan to leverage the connectivity offered by Sync to help drivers maintain their wellness on the go.

But the best news of all? Drivers don't have to pay a premium for a non-allergenic car. Every 2013 Fusion and 2013 Escape benefits from the research, and Ford says its other new cars will have to live up to the new allergy standards going forward.

pageElements.text: What makes a woman crazy about an automobile? I can only speak for myself. I grew up in the country surrounded by a dairy farm and five brothers. To me, cars were freedom. When I was fourteen years old, as an exchange student in Ecuador, I learned how to drive in a Toyota Land Cruiser high in the Andes Mountains, where they mark driver error with small white crosses. My fifteen-year-old Ecuadorian brother was my instructor. I never wanted to get out of that car again.

Violette Morris

Boxing, archery, diving, javelin throwing, weightlifting, soccer playing, Greco-Roman wrestling, racing...Violette Morris was quite a sportswoman. Add to that a bit of heroism, driving a Red Cross ambulance during the Battle of Verdun in World War I.

In 1922, she won the shot put and javelin competitions in the first female Olympic games, held in Monte Carlo. That same year, she entered the Bol d'Or twenty-four-hour endurance race in a 1922 Benjamin Type B cycle car and took fourth place, setting a lap record. She won the Paris-Pyrenees-Paris race in 1922 and was a class winner in the Paris-Nice in 1923.

Violette was famous for her athletic and automotive prowess, but she also drew attention by living openly as a lesbian, for dressing in men's suits, and for fistfighting during soccer matches. The French Women's Athletic Federation refused her request for a license renewal in 1927 and prevented her from participating in the 1928 Olympic summer games in Amsterdam. Violette made the news for electing to undergo a double mastectomy so she would be more comfortable behind the wheel. She ran an auto parts store in Paris until 1929.

In the mid-1930s, Violette was recruited by a member of the Nazi security service and invited to Berlin for the 1936 Olympic Summer Games, where she was received by Adolf Hitler with "much pomp and circumstance," according to Jean-Francois Bouzanquet, the author of Fast Ladies: Female Racing Drivers 1888-1970. After that, it was straight downhill to an evil end for Violette Morris. It's said she provided Germany with information that helped the Nazis take Paris in 1940. She spied for the Germans, transported black market goods, and was said to be an active torturer of resisters. On April 26, 1944, she was killed by members of the French Resistance while out driving in a supercharged Citroen.

pageElements.text: It's not every day that you find a compact cargo van worthy of excitement, but Nissan's NV200 mobile guitar repair shop, revealed at this week's New York Auto Show, is that rare cargo van.

The one-of-a-kind vehicle, officially known as the Gibson NV200 Mobile Repair & Restoration Van, is the realization of a partnership with Gibson that Nissan has been interested in for years, according to Nissan product communications manager Phil Lienert. But why the desire to connect with the storied guitar maker? Gibson and Nissan are both based in Tennessee and seek to provide "very desirable consumer goods" that are still accessible (and affordable) to skilled tradespeople.

Everything for the Luthier

The NV200 provided the perfect opportunity for Nissan to realize its dream collaboration. Working closely with the craftsmen at Gibson's Nashville Repair & Restoration shop, Nissan created a special version of the van fitted with a guitar rack, a sliding workbench (complete with tool set), and even a soldering station.

The interior of the Gibson one-off is a significant upgrade, with leather seats instead of the standard cloth: two up front for driver and passenger, and two stools in the cargo area, all emblazoned with the Gibson logo. The Gibson logo is also splashed across the hood and side panels of the van, so there's no mistaking it for something ordinary. The attractive wood veneer inserts in the rear cargo doors and dashboard are also sourced from Gibson.

It's only natural that a vehicle designed for musicians would have a designer stereo system, and this one boasts four retractable Onkyo speakers mounted in the doors and ceilings for deployment at special events.

Even though the Gibson NV200 is a prototype, Nissan has no intention of letting it sit in a warehouse after its turn at the auto show. "This is a working car, and we're going to put it to work," Lienert assured me. Details are still being worked out, but expect to see the repair van at big music and car events in the future.

pageElements.text: Free is good. We all know that. At the New York Auto Show, Hyundai proved that it knows how to hand out good free stuff when it announced its new Assurance Connected Care program. This is an expansion of the existing Hyundai Assurance program, which grows to include more services this spring when it combines with Hyundai Blue Link telematics.  One of the most important things I learned during my time as a college student was that you should almost always take advantage of free goods or services when they are offered to you (exceptions for unknown substances and food that has already touched the ground). So Hyundai definitely got my attention with this announcement.

Assurance Connected Care will be free for three years in all cars that come equipped with Blue Link, starting on May 16, 2013. That includes most models of the Veloster, Elantra GT, Sonata, Sonata Hybrid, Azera, Genesis Coupe, Genesis, and Santa Fe. Assurance Connected Care includes Hyundai's powertrain and new car warranties and free twenty-four-hour roadside assistance, as well as eight existing Blue Link features: Automatic Collision Notification, SOS Emergency Assistance, Maintenance Alerts, and Vehicle Diagnostics, among others. Check out all the icons in our photo gallery.

The three-year free trial for Assurance Connected Care can also be transferred to subsequent owners of a vehicle.

How the Money Breaks Down

Blue Link's current basic package contains just four of those features and costs $79 per year after a six-month free trial. In order to get all eight of the soon-to-be-free features, current users have to step up to the Blue Link Essentials package, which costs $179 per year after a three-month trial. Once Blue Link officially migrates to the Assurance program, the existing Essentials package will take a hefty price cut. Future buyers will pay just $99 for that package, which includes remote control of door locks, geofencing, speed alerts (especially of interest if you have a household with teen drivers), and voice text messaging capability.

Another Consumer-Friendly Move from Hyundai

Launched during the depths of the recession, Hyundai Assurance started with a buyback program that allowed customers who lost their jobs within one year of purchasing a new Hyundai to return the car and end their loan obligation. Hyundai would cover the difference between the trade-in value of the car and the amount left on the loan, and customers would suffer no ill effects to their credit ratings.

Hyundai is quick to point out that Assurance Connected Care will put it at the top of the heap for provision of free safety services. The GM's OnStar Safe and Sound package, which offers many of the same features as Assurance Connected Care, has six-month, one-year, and two-year free trials for Chevrolet, Cadillac, and Buick drivers, respectively, and then costs $199 per year after that. Toyota offers a year-long free trial of its Safety Connect services that costs $139 after the trial is over, but that trial doesn't match Hyundai's for number of services.
Will Assurance Connected Care make you more likely to buy a Hyundai, or are you unmoved by the promise of a long free trial?

pageElements.text: Researching and picking out a new car are exhilarating, but the buying process can be daunting. Cars are expensive, and there’s a general feeling that the odds of getting a good deal are stacked against the buyer. Huddy Skiba, sales manager at Hyman Bros. Mazda in Newport News, Virginia, says that when customers walk into a car dealership, they are "terrified that they’re going to be ripped off. We’re just trying to help."

We want to help, too, so we’ve put together a few pieces of advice to help unravel the mysteries of shopping for your new car. Doing your homework before you ever walk into a dealership can go a long way toward making you feel more confident, so this week we’ll be talking about what to think about before you finance a car.

For our final installment, we’ll talk about the intricacies of loan length.

The Big Tradeoff: Payment Size vs. Interest

Most car loans are between thirty-six and sixty months long. Naturally, shorter loans will have higher monthly payments but they'll also accrue less interest, so you’ll pay less overall by the time the loan is paid off. On the other hand, longer loans and lower monthly payments may be crucial to fitting a car into your budget. Even a seventy-two-month loan has become relatively common in these days of high car prices.

What should really determine loan length is how long you plan to keep your car. Signing a five-year loan with low monthly payments may seem like a good idea, but if you’re planning on dumping your car for a newer model after two years, you’ll still have a large balance when you start shopping for a car again.

Don't Let Yourself Go Upside Down

The key is to avoid owing more money than the car is worth. This is more likely to happen if you have a long loan and a high interest rate and make a small down payment because your vehicle’s value may depreciate faster than you can pay off the principal on your loan. This could cause problems if your insurance provider won’t cover the car for as much as you owe, or if you are looking to trade your car in and can’t negotiate a value that allows you to pay off your existing loan.

The Moment of Truth: Heading into the Dealership

We’ve said this before, but it bears repeating: if you did all your homework, made all your decisions, and you still can’t come to a reasonable agreement with your dealer, walk out. Buying a car is a big investment and not one that you should be pressured into. Take all the time you need to get a deal you feel comfortable with, and if you don’t think you can reach a deal with the salesperson you’re working with, ask for a different salesperson or find yourself a new dealer. There’s no reason to be nervous, though. Skiba believes that buyers who have done their homework and walk into the dealership armed with plenty of information have every reason to expect a good deal.

There’s a lot more to say about the process of buying a car. We hope that this series has helped demystify the lead-up to walking in to the dealership. We’ll be back soon with more tips on the rest of the buying process.

pageElements.text: April isn’t just the first month of reliably springlike weather here in Michigan: it’s also National Distracted Driving Awareness Month. To help us all get in an awareness-raising kind of mood, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has just released data that estimates that at any given daylight moment, there are 660,000 distracted drivers on the roads in the United States, which, you’ve got to admit, is a little alarming.

In a separate report, also released this month, NHTSA surveyed 6,000 licensed drivers on their distracted driving practices. That survey showed that while Americans are concerned about distracted driving—74 percent of respondents favored a ban on handheld cell phone use while driving, and a whopping 94 percent supported a texting ban—we’re not quite practicing what we preach.

How Much Will You Admit?

NHTSA says that about 49 percent of drivers would admit to taking an incoming call while driving, though only about 24 percent said they would place a call from behind the wheel. Only fourteen percent admitted to sending text messages while driving, which seems to indicate that drivers are at least aware of the dangers of texting while driving, even if they sometimes do it anyway.

In Michigan, teens with learner's permits are now banned from using cell phones at all while behind the wheel. (See related story.) That's just one example of anti-distraction legislation around the country. But don’t assume that teenagers are the only ones succumbing to the pull of the smartphone when they should be focused on the road. NHTSA’s survey identified affluent drivers with college degrees as some of the most prone to distraction. Least prone to distraction? Those over sixty-five. Only five percent of drivers in that age group were classified as distraction prone.

Hands-Free Is Not the Panacea, Either

We can all relate to people who drive distracted. Cell phones have made us constantly available, and driving doesn’t always feel like a good excuse to ignore a call from your boss or a text from your kid. I don’t text while driving—a decision made easier by driving a manual—but I do sometimes talk on the phone while driving. I use a hands-free device, but the Department of Transportation says that is not “substantially safer” than holding the phone up to my ear.

And I'm not alone. I’m often in the car with friends who text while driving, but even though they admit that they shouldn’t, they usually finish the text anyway. In fact, the only people I know who never glance at or fiddle with their phones while driving are the ones who don’t drive. That’s all the more reason to observe National Distracted Driving Awareness Month. Let’s all take this opportunity to remember how important it is to turn a blind eye—and ear—to our phones while we’re driving, and maybe by next month, our phones won’t seem as tempting.
