pageElements.text: Would you give up your car if you had 100 Teslas on standby?

It might seem odd to go out and buy 100 cars when your aim is to get people to give up cars, but things are different in Las Vegas. Project 100, part of the larger Downtown Project, has just signed an agreement to buy 100 Tesla Model S electric cars that will be available for people to use in the city on an as-needed basis.
Personally, I might find the “need” pretty often if I were one of the limited number of dues-paying members who will get the opportunity to get into a Model S.

It’s all part of an ambitious urban improvement project in the neon capital of the world.  A group of visionaries have plans that range from a social center made out of storage crates, to be populated by art galleries and cafes, to downtown speaker series and family events. Their aim is to get people to gather and connect by making it easier to move around in the city. They say wonky things like, “we see an opportunity to hack density,” and “[we’re] working to increase collisions between people.”
But not collisions between Teslas, naturally. The catch to this scheme is that you don’t get to drive the Model S, only to be chauffeured in it by a paid driver.

Here’s How It Works

Here’s the plan. You sign up to be part of the Project 100 “complete transportation system.” Like all the best new tech, it’s in beta and is invitation only for the next few months. Once a member, you download a mobile app and then you can order up what you need to get around. There will be 100-plus “on demand drivers,” 100-plus shared cars, 100-plus shared bicycles, and 100-plus shared shuttle bus stops, all available for the approximately $400-a-month membership fee.

The choices will be: be picked up by a driver in a Tesla within three minutes, walk up to two-tenths of a mile to drive yourself in a much less pricey low-range electric vehicle such as a Polaris GEM, borrow a bicycle, or take a “party bus” that will be stopping every four minutes around the city.

Project 100 is structuring the plan around a series of urban zones. Charging stations will be based around the downtown area, and the logistics of getting people to vehicles and vehicles to people will be a complex algorithm that the group is working on now.

Who’s Behind It?

If you like buying shoes from Zappos, you probably know that the founder, Nick Swinmurn, started really small. I mean, really small. He started out just snapping pictures of shoes from retail stores, posting them online, and offering to buy and ship them to a small customer base. The scheme turned out pretty well for the company, now headed by CEO Tony Hsieh. And Hsieh has now turned his attention to the urban revitalization problem, and with his track record of turning ideas into gold, it just might work.

So you can’t imagine riding a bicycle over to the casino? These people want Las Vegas to be more than that. Would you give up your car if the infrastructure for transportation were easy enough to use?

Dubai’s fuzz have their own V-12s now, and they’re not afraid to use them.

The desert city’s police force announced in mid-April that they would be adding a Lamborghini Aventador to their patrol fleet, presumably to intimidate drivers who are looking to take advantage of the area’s open desert highways to verify top speed on their expensive sports cars.

Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Auto racing is a fabulous spectacle, whether seen in person or on TV. The tracks are huge theaters. When followed regularly, the sport offers the rewards—and sometimes pain—of human drama. Drivers and mechanics struggle against adversity, use their athletic ability under extreme circumstances in concert with machinery, and face injury and death.
No matter what the racing series, rules ensure that competition is tight: three-tenths of a second per lap is a huge advantage.

The show goes on ten months of the year. Changing backdrops add interest. Rivalries are played out to stunning effect. Villains emerge. Like most soap operas, there’s even a hospital: every track has an infield care center.
Here’s a look at the different major leagues of racing and why your interest may be rewarded:

Formula 1

Growing out of competition among aristocrats in quest of the Grand Prix, or top prize, of European nations before World War II, Formula 1 fields highly advanced automobiles.

The open-wheel cars (meaning the wheels sit outside the body) look like stick insects on wheels, and their tiny but potent V-8 engines, situated behind the drivers, shriek like unleashed geophysical forces. The drivers—no women, currently—tend to be slightly larger than jockeys; their daily gym workouts are grueling.

Truly global, F1 holds its glittering events everywhere from Shanghai to central Texas. The races are conducted on purpose-built tracks with numerous turns, both sweeping fast ones and tight and fast ones. Monaco’s famous race, the Monaco Grand Prix, scheduled for May 26, follows streets in this principality on the Riviera. The season goes from March to November. This year's U.S. Grand Prix is the penultimate event, held on November 17 at the Circuit of the Americas in Austin, Texas.

Technologies refined in F1—antilock brakes, electronic management of engines and other components, and even tire design—filter down to your driveway. The byzantine rules require cars to weigh at minimum 1,420 pounds—less than half the weight of a Ford Focus—and coin strange terms for parts like the modesty panels over the nose, which are an aerodynamic factor.

So who cares? We know a woman in Los Angeles, the proud owner of a BMW, who used to rise at three a.m. on Sunday morning to watch the Hungarian Grand Prix. Now she sleeps the night through but enjoys the recorded races at a friend’s house.

NASCAR

The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) emphasizes entertainment over technology. Its Sprint Cup championship series is America’s most popular racing league.

NASCAR first raced regular Chevrolets and other familiar makes that were modified with speed parts developed by moonshiners. They ran on short tracks in the Southeast and the shoreline at Daytona Beach. The preeminent tradition of oval superspeedways arose at Darlington, South Carolina, and the massive 2.5-mile track built at Daytona in 1959.
Now, although the cars’ bodies must be identically shaped, they still look like Fords, Chevrolets, and Toyotas, thanks to good graphic design. All entries use the same roaring V-8 engine.

NASCAR’s tremendous TV ratings are due in large part to huge crashes, which rarely cause injury because of the cars’ internal reinforcement. Top drivers have long careers. Ally yourself with one, perhaps Danica Patrick, and you’ll watch every week.

IndyCar

The Izod IndyCar Series has roots at obscure one-mile horse tracks in Illinois and Indiana, as well as the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, where the 500-mile race was first run in 1911.

Today’s IndyCar league is similar to Formula 1. The cars are open wheeled like those in F1, but IndyCar's racing cars have turbocharged V-6 engines and a semi-batwing shape. Street circuits, oval tracks large and small, and dedicated road-racing circuits are used. All races are in North America except one in Brazil, where several IndyCar drivers come from.
Currently, Simona de Silvestro is the league’s top woman, and some are betting on her to become the second female IndyCar race winner after Danica Patrick.

Endurance and Sports Car Racing

In France, the 24 Hours of Le Mans has been one of the world’s more important races since 1923, when it was initiated. A unique, wedgy sports-prototype car has developed for the top formula, rather like an F1 car with fenders. Audi’s dominant cars use hybrid turbodiesel-and-electric propulsion systems. Four-driver teams split shifts behind the wheel.
Other competitive classes at Le Mans include very close relatives of roadgoing Ferraris, Porsches, and Corvettes.

In America, the American Le Mans Series (ALMS) practices a similar discipline, with races held on city streets (Baltimore, Maryland, and Long Beach, California) as well as dedicated circuits like Road Atlanta, which every October hosts the season-ending Petit Le Mans, covering 1,000 miles or ten hours, whichever comes first. ALMS races offer a glittery, high-toned atmosphere similar to that of Formula 1.

Drag Racing

The National Hot Rod Association (NHRA) grew from match races held at local airports and paved quarter-mile strips, and it’s still a hoot. Four big-time classes use widely different formulas: Top Fuel, Funny Car, Pro Stock, and Pro Stock Motorcycle. Outrageous invention characterizes drag racing, and the cars and bikes are like living, fire-breathing cartoons.

Women are increasingly involved in the NHRA. Because drag racing is good TV fare, picking your own icon of speed can lead to an engaging experience—maybe even to your own participation during the local track’s amateur night.
Incidentally, because of their treadless tires, known as slicks, the NHRA and NASCAR are the only major leagues that stop the action when raindrops fall.

pageElements.text: What the heck happened to Team 303 in Italy? you ask. The last you might remember was that my teammate, Mercedes-Benz USA CEO Steve Cannon, and I were waiting at the Teatro Grande in the center of Brescia, staring at Gina Lollobrigida, trying desperately to find a working cell tower and waiting for the evening start of the Mille Miglia. (Read Part One and Part Two of this tale, if you haven't already; then come back.)

Obviously, something went very wrong. If you follow JeanKnowsCars on Twitter, you already know from a handful of sporadic posts that we were able to send in rare moments of cellular service that our lovely old 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300SL Gullwing had terminal engine failure a mere 50.4 miles from the start. Here’s the long version of our sad story.

Thursday evening: It's time to leave the Opera House and join the stream of Ferraris old and new blasting through the dense crowd of spectators. No worries about finding our way. The route out of downtown is mobbed on both sides of the street, despite the rain, the wind, and the fact that it’s the middle of the day and the middle of the week. Young men are sauntering brazenly into the path of the cars with hats cocked sideways, while grandmas are sweeping their hands encouraging more speed. Little kids are waving flags. Traffic lights do not exist. We are heroes. At every intersection, police are waving us through. Every agente di polizia with a scooter is on it and assigned (or self-assigned, for all we know) to the race. Stirling Moss is right: Brescia is in a frenzy.

And we are only going to the museum. Another couple of hours, another groaning buffet. "Are we supposed to be carbo loading for this?" Cannon asks. He is serious. This is a guy who won the Phys Ed award at West Point, which is saying something. I am the exact opposite. "Yes," I say, equally serious.

Our wall of gray-jacketed Mercedes-Benz mechanics is waiting by our car with crates of snacks, water, and a bag of supplies that includes flashlights on headbands, hand wipes, eyeglass wipes, and on and on.

They should strike, if not fear, than intense jealousy into the hearts of the competition. Mercedes is not only the main event sponsor, but the fifteen-car factory team includes board members Thomas Weber and Joachim Schmidt and head of PR Jörg Howe, among other luminaries including former Formula 1 drivers Jochen Mass, Karl Wendlinger, and David Coulthard, who watches the courtyard full of cars firing up from an open window in a tower above the crowd. “I’m going to do a Le Mans start,” he shouts down to me. Which means he is going to run down the stairs, leap into the car, and take off. Such a joker, this one.

We feel like we're in a protective cocoon of fabulousness and invincibility. That, of course, would be wrong. We are dashed to earth immediately on leaving the museum for the starting ramp. We're directed out the back driveway, and we pop out into traffic with no idea where we are and without sight of a single other of the 400-plus competitors. I have no idea which way we're even pointed.
"Not again," I say.
"I think I remember that building," says Cannon. We both start laughing. "We have an hour to go two miles," I remind him.

Just as we notice the crowd walking on the sidewalk suddenly thicken, we come around a turn and join the throng of vintage cars and trucks, driven by entrants from twenty-eight countries, clogging the street in front of us. We have joined the 2013 Mille Miglia. Within no time, we are waved off amid the cheers of the crowd, the roar of our engine, and the sounds of our names over the loudspeaker.
I tell Steve I'm absolutely overwhelmed and close to tears. "Not just you," he says to me.

It is really overwhelming. And it’s hard not to go as fast as possible, even though this is merely a re-creation of a very real and brutal race, which ran from 1927 to 1957. The end came when popular Formula 1 driver Alfonso de Portago crashed near the finish in Brescia, killing himself, his co-driver, and nine spectators.
The crowd wants fast, even from Team 303, which means that 302 cars in front of us already gave them fast, and they are still there, as excited for us as they were for car number 1.

From Start to Finish

I’m an overachiever navigator. That means I go through the book with a highlighter, and I mark every potential place we could miss a turn. There were so many roundabouts one on top of another and opportunities to get lost that I had highlighted half the book. I was feeling really good that I had marked the whole first leg, from Brescia to Ferrara, a total of 158.5 miles. I would worry about leg two, Ferrara to Rome, once we got in.

This was going to be the easy night, and as it turned out, we really didn’t need to worry so much about the turns, because even into the night, the route was lined with spectators pointing the way. There was a policeman at every turn pointing to the turn. There was a Mille Miglia arrow signboard pointing the correct way.

About fifty miles into the event, night had fallen and we had entered the ancient walled city of Verona. The last time I was in Verona, I saw Franco Zeffirelli's Carmen in the Roman amphitheater. At intermission, I drank champagne with Zeffirelli, he of the dyed yellow hair and orange skin, neither color found in nature. It was an emotional experience, and as we passed the amphitheater and I was telling Steve the story, I got choked up again.

In the end, tears would have been the correct emotional response to our time in Verona. We got into a traffic jam almost immediately, right by the amphitheater. All the race cars were around us. Cars were overheating right and left. Some were making U-turns and going down side streets. Others had their drivers pushing them.

We crept along and crept along. At one point, we were side by side with Roger Penske and Mario Illien, and we shouted to one another like it was old home week and joked about Mario’s array of high-tech timers stuck across the dash on the passenger’s side that he was using to negotiate the strictly timed portions of the rally.
They were clearly in it to win it. We were more in it to not spin it.

One of the organizers came through the gigantic traffic jam of stopped racing cars, handing out new directions for leaving Verona because the route was partly flooded. This did not bode well for the rest of the event, since weather forecasts called for continuous heavy rain and high winds. In the end, we didn’t have to worry about that, because just as we came within view of the timing control point where our time card was to be stamped, steam began to pour from the engine. As one, we looked at the water temperature gauge. "It’s on 0, it’s not working," said Steve. He tapped on it. I tapped on it and looked closer and I said, "Oh it’s working, it’s pegged."

Our engine had overheated and was pouring steam out, and Steve immediately got on the phone to the mechanics. They told him, "Turn it off, wait until the temperature gets down to 80 degrees, fill it with water, and you’ll be fine."
We sat within view of the timing stand as the other cars inched past us, one after another.
After thirty minutes, the temperature was still at 100 degrees. As the last of the stragglers were passing the control point, our temperature was still at 90, and we decided to go for it.
Once we cleared off the steam and heat, we filled the whole thing with water, fired up the engine, and watched white smoke billow from the tailpipe.

Steve revved it a few times, and more and more white smoke came out. Everyone standing around looked at it and said aloud what we knew in our hearts was true: there was water in the engine, which was not a good sign.

We went through the control, got our time card stamped, and went down the road just outside the city wall. Then we pulled over under a streetlight and parked, hoping it wasn’t true, but knowing that our race was over.

The mechanics were an hour away, but we were kept company by people who had come to watch the rally and now had one car that they could just sit and stare at. So they did. We were never alone, always with bystanders. As some drifted away, others came.

One person stood and watched the entire time, making occasional comments in French. In the U.S., we don't have that kind of time. We'd be all, "Dude, looks bad, need help? No? Okay, gotta run."  Not our Frenchman. He stood by while we waited for our guys to either rescue us and get us running or tell us the race was over.

The End

No one wants to be out, least of all the mechanics, who have worked hard on the cars, brought them to Italy, and had individual sessions with each driver to explain the idiosyncrasies unique to each of our sixty-year-old sports cars. I have never met a racing mechanic who didn't think that, if given a chance, he could outrace his driver.

It must have been brutal for our rescue team—Klaus, Sven, and Nate Lander from the Mercedes-Benz Classic Center in the U.S.—to see us out of the race and not wonder what they would or could have done differently to prevent our car from overheating. What if we'd pushed it along the traffic-clogged streets of Verona instead of firing it up?

But no. Klaus apologized. "It is our fault. We gave you a car that had a problem." He was sincere in suggesting that the problem was very likely lurking below the surface and had just worked its way to the fore. This is the beauty of being on Team Mercedes-Benz. Great guys, great cars, great organization.

The decision was made to flatbed the Gullwing about an hour south to Ferrara, where a fresh crew of mechanics could possibly change the head gasket, if parts were available. During the wait, they added water and ran the car up and down the street, causing both black smoke on acceleration and white smoke on deceleration, indicating there was water in the engine.
It felt like waiting for the College of Cardinals to vote for the new pope. They pulled spark plugs, which were surprisingly dry, and they pulled the dipstick to look for water.

The flatbed arrived, along with a phone call letting us know we had no spare parts. By then, we'd arranged the mechanics' luggage and parts in their GL support vehicle to hold our stuff, too. A head gasket wouldn't have fit in that stuffed GL.

pageElements.text: This is the third video in a series, in which I spend some quality time behind the wheel with Elle and Rose, two teenage girls in the process of getting their driver's licenses. We've previously talked about getting set up properly behind the wheel in Part 1 and learning to drive in reverse while using your mirrors in Part 2.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/rX3w-fYIpEQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

What's in This Video

In this installment, Elle and Rose learn more about being smooth drivers by understanding what tires can (and can't) do. We talk about the weight transfer that happens when you accelerate, brake, and turn.

Heavy acceleration or braking while the weight is transferring upsets not only your passengers but also the equilibrium of the tires. When the tires are at their limit—that is, when they're making that terrifying screaming noise—the last thing you should do is stress them further by suddenly braking or adding gas. The tires can't take it, and they can completely lose their grip, resulting in a spin or a crash.

Watch the load transfer on the video. I think they got the basic idea after a few turns around the parking lot, don't you? I couldn't bring myself to actually spin the car and freak them out. Or make them vomit on me. Ahem.

Why Am I Doing This Series?

I’ve been racking up to 100,000 miles a year since my late teenage years, when I was a taxicab owner/operator. There is nothing I love to do more than to teach kids the driving secrets I’ve learned over the miles. Damn. I wish had me around when I was their age. I would have told me how stupid it was to drive everywhere at 100 miles an hour. I would have learned emergency maneuvers long before I actually had to make one.
Of course, there is nothing like, oh, a few million or so miles behind the wheel, with a chunk of that at high speed on a racetrack, to give you a tad of well-earned confidence behind the wheel.
At least I learned how to drive a stick before I saw my first automatic.

So here I am, ready to serve. This isn’t a comprehensive driver’s ed class. I’m aiming with the No. 1 Ladies' Driving Academy to share the things I’ve learned wayyy outside the classroom. I want kids to know as many different ways as possible of getting out of trouble on the road. Like, say, avoiding it altogether.
I will keep making these videos as long as there are kids (and don’t take that Ladies thing seriously; boys Я allowed) with new questions about how to do whatever it is they are afraid of doing.
Ask and you will receive.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text: If you have even a passing interest in electric or other alternative-powered vehicles, you have probably noticed high-profile EV maker Tesla Motors. Lately, Tesla CEO Elon Musk has been talking strategy and making big promises. He said in an interview last week that Tesla is targeting an affordable electric car with 200 miles of range, which he hopes the company will be ready to sell within three to four years. By “affordable,” he means less than $40,000.

The least expensive incarnation of Tesla’s current offering, the Model S, will set buyers back more than $62,400 after a $7,500 federal tax incentive, so pricing under $40,000 seems a long way off. Nevertheless, this news, coming on the heels of Tesla’s announcement that it’s paying back government loans ahead of schedule, is more proof that electric vehicles are entering the mainstream. Just this week, Tesla also announced the dramatic expansion of its Supercharger network; it could let Tesla owners charge up their vehicles for free all the way across the country within a year.

Tesla is far from the only producer of electric cars aiming to lower the barriers to entry for electric car ownership. In recent weeks, several auto companies have announced aggressive leasing deals to entice consumers to try out EVs. Snag one, and you could drive off in an EV with a much lower monthly payment than you might have for a similar car that’s traditionally powered.
Here are a few things that make driving electric more wallet-friendly than you might expect.

Lease Deals

Affordable leasing deals for electric cars seem to be the latest rage in car sales. From Tesla to Chevrolet, if you’re thinking of buying an EV, there’s probably a lease deal out there for you. Here are some that are in effect now:

• Fiat 500e (right): It’s only available in California, but if you live there, the Italian automaker has a 36-month, $999 down, $199 a month lease plan for you.
• Nissan Leaf: There’s a 36-month, $199 a month lease deal for the 2013 Leaf, The down payment of $1,999 is quite a bit heftier than the 500e’s.
• Chevrolet Spark EV: The 2014 Spark EV, on sale this summer, will match the 500e’s down payment and monthly payment.

• Honda Fit EV: Starting June 1, Honda is getting in on the game with changes to the Fit EV’s lease plan: the monthly payment for a Fit EV will drop more than $100, from $389 to $259, and a new three-year lease option does away with a down payment.

Tax Incentives

Since many carmakers advertise EV prices minus federal tax incentives, those incentives alone might not be enough to banish sticker shock. But tax incentives can lop thousands of dollars off an electric car’s sticker price, depending on the car and where you live. Buyers can receive a federal tax incentive of up to $7,500 on their new EVs, depending on the car’s battery capacity. Some state and local governments offer further incentives, so if you’re lucky, you could lop as much as $10,000 off the price of your new car.

Lower Costs

At the end of the day, you can’t deny that electric cars carry an initial premium over their gasoline-powered counterparts. But what automakers are hoping is that potential buyers will do some key calculations about the cost of EV ownership. Most obviously, the drivers of electric cars don’t have to shell out for a fresh tank of gas every few hundred miles. Electric cars can typically be charged for as little as a few dollars, and some electric cars also have lower maintenance costs when compared to traditional cars since they have fewer moving parts and don’t require oil and other fluid changes.

Owning an electric car isn’t for everyone—people who drive hundreds of miles per day, for instance, are probably better off sticking with internal-combustion engines for now—but if you’re teetering on the edge of EV ownership, these savings are worth plugging into your calculations.

pageElements.text: The Lincoln Motor Company is reinventing itself, and it has a few tricks up its sleeve to help remind us all that Lincoln means luxury.  One of those tricks, standard in Lincoln’s 2013 MKZ, MKS, and MKT models, is continuously controlled damping. It may not have the most exciting name, but it’ll save you from the harsh realities of pothole season, and that more than makes up for the uninspiring moniker.

The continuously controlled damping system is designed to ensure optimal ride comfort regardless of road conditions. The system uses no fewer than forty-six data inputs to analyze road conditions and adjust damping forces up to twenty times per second.

The system can switch among Sport, Normal, and Comfort modes in real time, so if you run over a pothole with your front wheels, the system will have adjusted the suspension’s firmness by the time your back wheels hit. This won’t just improve your comfort, it could also help prevent damage to your car from rough impacts. Lincoln says the system is quick enough to tighten the car’s suspension instantly on contact with a pothole. Instant means that it can prevent the tire from traveling the full depth of the pothole, and that's what you want.

Pothole Awareness Is Good No Matter What You're Driving

Even if your car doesn’t benefit from Lincoln’s clever engineering, there are steps you can take to avoid damage from pesky road imperfections. Here are a few tips:

1. Make sure your tires are properly inflated (you can find your recommended tire pressure in your owner’s manual or inside your car’s driver’s side door). This will lessen the chances that a pothole will damage your car’s wheels.
2. Try to drive slowly over potholes, but don’t brake heavily to avoid them. This causes your car’s front suspension to compress and makes it less able to handle uneven road surfaces. Check out Jean’s video about speed bumps for the full rundown.
3. If you do get into a tangle with a particularly nasty pothole, be alert for signs that it may have damaged your car. A sudden vibration or change in ride quality could indicate that something’s amiss.

What I Think:

Redesigned for 2013, the Nissan Altima has a newly distinctive exterior—note the kinked taillamps and the larger front grille—and more available technology than ever before. The Altima is one of the bestselling cars in its segment; more than 140,000 of them have left dealer lots since the start of 2013. We decided to take one for a spin to see what all the fuss is about.

The top-of-the-line Nissan Altima 3.5SL we tested has every option that’s available for this mid-size sedan. The SL trim level is decked out with a nine-speaker Bose audio system, leather seats, keyless entry and push-button start, and a heated steering wheel. The 3.5SL’s standard 270-horsepower V-6 engine offers an 88-horsepower boost over the base Altima’s four-cylinder engine but still manages 31 mpg on the highway, thanks to a fuel-saving continuously variable transmission. The optional technology package gives this Altima a seven-inch navigation display, blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and moving object detection for just $1,090.

All that technology could get overwhelming, but the Altima doesn’t feel bogged down with buttons or blinking lights. The driver information display in the dash allows the driver to toggle through the various systems and their settings with ease, and the infotainment system was simple to operate, even though I didn’t spend fifteen minutes in the parking lot with an owner’s manual figuring it all out.

The Altima feels spacious and luxurious inside, a vehicle designed for family trips or long commutes. Driving the Altima around town, the V-6 engine provided more than ample power to accelerate off red lights, but its true calling is as a slightly sub-luxury daily driver. The whole car—from the wide, soft seats to the smooth ride to the steering—feels a little soft. But that’s not necessarily a bad thing. With its floaty ride and somewhat ponderous steering response, the Altima isn’t the right car to take around a handling course, but it’s perfect for eating up highway miles in total comfort.

The Verdict:

The Altima 3.5SL manages to deliver a lot of luxury for a fairly affordable price. The $32,135 model we tested is the most expensive Altima money can buy, but it makes up for it by being absolutely packed with content. The powertrain is powerful and satisfying without guzzling gas, and the interior is comfortable and attractive. This car isn’t quite right for my lifestyle, but if you are a person who has a longer commute or needs something with a usable rear seat, the Altima should have your attention.
